description:
Men's Group Tuesday 14 Oct, To join this community, and book your Tuesdays - please sign up here first, and we will email you the event access code. (our venue address will be emailed with your ticket).

This is a space for men to talk honestly, listen deeply, and figure some things out together. It’s not about having it all sorted. You don’t need to be a certain type of guy. Just show up as you are, with no pressure to speak or share.
Open group: new faces are welcome
Flexible: book to come when it suits you. Each Tuesday is a new event. Most will try for fortnightly.
Small groups: 8 men + 2 experienced hosts
Inclusive: all ages, backgrounds and identities (18+)
It's about connection and showing up, instead of going it alone. It makes time for meeting our various challenges, while learning and growing us into better friends, partners, dads, sons and humans. 
It isn’t a boys or bros club, therapy or a self-help seminar, religious or new-age. No fixing, preaching, or pressure. It’s not a crisis service or a substitute for professional care. The sign-up form explains this in more detail.
You can expect to:
Practice listening and learn communication skills for life
Discover greater integrity and self-accountability
Be supported in building your emotional intelligence
Become a part of a hearty and diverse community
Have a good time - it’s often uplifting and inspiring.
Joseph and your team of hosts have all been in regular men's groups for many years. The group sometimes offers simple and proven inquiries that draw on NVC, MBSR, active listening, gratitude and more.

description:
Social Sewing Saturday - October, Social Sewing Saturday - October
Come join us for a fun-filled day of sewing and socializing at Karori Arts & Crafts!

About this Event

Come join us for a fun-filled day of sewing and socializing at Karori Arts & Crafts! Whether you're a seasoned pro or just starting out, this event is perfect for anyone who loves to sew. Bring your latest project or start something new - either way, you'll have a blast chatting with fellow sewing enthusiasts. Bring your current project or get inspired by others' creations at our friendly gathering. Share tips, tricks, and stories while working on our projects together.
Don't forget to pack your sewing machine, fabric, and any other supplies you'll need. We can't wait to see what you create! You will need to bring your own machine and materials. Please bring an extension lead and multipoint box if you have one. (Don't worry, though—we have some in the centre, too!) We'll supply an iron and ironing board to share, as well as a table and relatively comfy chair each. There are also spare cutting-out tables at a taller height. You are welcome to come along and work on hand-sewing projects.
A kitchen is available on site and supermarkets as well as cafes are very close by.Parking is free and there are 3 dedicated spaces for the centre as well as others closeby.
Cost: Free for members of the Karori Arts Centre or $15 per person payable directly to KACC. (Membership of the centre is $105 annually and also gives you reductions on classes and access to other groups)
Please do NOT attend if you are sick (even just a little bit!)

description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA
On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.

***

PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK 🩷 LA VITA IN ROSA 🩷 LEVEN IN ROZE 🩷 LA VIDA EN ROSA 🩷 LA VIE EN ROSE 🩷 ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO 🩷 AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.

***

CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.

What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.

Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!

Dress Code: PINK!

Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!

Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!

EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:

02-0343-0003801-007

ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.

Please give generously.

LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.

NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.

RAIN DATE: TBC

***

This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.

#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban

Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening

This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer

And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump

Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness

Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.

description:
Sir Dave Dobbyn — Selected Songs, He’s a treasured musical voice in New Zealand culture. Sir Dave Dobbyn has over 45 years of experience as a singer, songwriter, and recording artist. For one special night, he will be singing in Wellington at The Opera House. Many of his songs have acted as a backdrop to Kiwis’ lives and shaped the sound of the country’s popular music scene. Some of Dave’s songs are so famous that they have become anthems. You’ll get to hear many of them along with rich pickings from his back catalogue. 
Diagnosed with Parkinson’s Disease in 2022, Dave declared it “business as usual” — and continues to inspire with his unmistakable voice and enduring stage presence. Recognised with a Knighthood in 2021 for his services to music, Dave remains one of New Zealand’s most revered cultural figures.

description:
Jewellery-making in 8 weeks - Tuesday Eve Mixed Level, This class is mixed level, allowing beginners to work alongside advanced students. It starts on Tuesday, 14 October and runs for 8 weeks till Tuesday, 2 December, 5.30pm - 8pm.
Our popular weeknight classes are the best way for beginners to get into jewellery making in a lively, warm and friendly environment.

Beginners start with basic ring-making and stone-setting in copper or brass. Students will learn measuring, texturing, shaping, cutting and soldering. Then we move on to making a practice-ring set with a Cabochon stone (cabochon means it has a flat bottom and a smooth domed top) in a Bezel Setting. The stone-setting process teaches you many fundamental techniques in one project! As you work through your practice-ring and setting, you can move onto working in silver and produce another ring with a cabachon stone that you really love. This way you will learn the basics as you go on your practice-ring, before taking the next step in costly silver.

Level 2 students learn to solder more competently on their own using chainmaking as a way to develop their fine soldering skills. They may create a simple stone setting or ring alongside this challenge project so they have something to hone their skills that they are familiar with, as well as taking on a new skill. Their silver project could be a pendant on a handmade chain, a charm bracelet or a more complex bezel setting - for example a teardrop or soft square stone to take on bezels with corners!

Level 3 and above students are encouraged to work on their design skills and try new and challenging techniques. They should prepare to have one or two simple projects they can work on self-directed in class: more chains or simple bezel settings are ideal - to help them strengthen their soldering skills - alongside a challenge project that might be a shelf setting (an adaptation of a bezel setting that can take faceted stones), a tube setting or a larger bezel setting for a box or brooch. Our tutors will work with you to discover your passions in the world of making, and to support your skills so you grow your understanding with each block you take. We recommend that students from level 3 and up take the occasional Technique class (for example - claw setting, enamelling, flush setting) and then bring those techniques into their projects in their block class to be supported in their practice and skill by their regular tutor.

This class fee does NOT include materials for any student.
Beginners should expect to spend at least $60 on materials for their ring making project.
All metals and stones as well as quality findings and chains are available for purchase each week in the studio. Students are encouraged to keep their silver scrap and find ways to use it thriftily in future projects!

Our booking system asks for payment to be made via credit card, Afterpay or PayPal on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this ;)

description:
Jewellery-making in 4 weeks on Sundays, Mixed levels - Wellington, This Sunday afternoon block is a short course on jewellery-making. It starts on Sun 24 August and runs for 4 weeks until Sun 14 September, 2pm - 5pm.
Beginners will practice the basic techniques in copper or brass and then move on to working in silver. An excellent first project for beginners in this class is to create a simple textured ring band - but once you have the basics down, it is fun to create earrings, pendants or other simple items. Learning to cut, heat, form and texture metal - to solder using a jeweller's torch and silver solder, and finally to polish your work up to a beautiful finish: these classes are super satisfying.
These blocks are also a nice way for existing students or more advanced makers to work on more challenging projects and join friendly classes in our well-equipped warm studio!
Basic materials are supplied and there are extra materials available to purchase as you need in class.
This block is great for teens and kids over 12 or so. NOTE: Anyone under 16 must be accompanied by an enrolled parent or caregiver.
Our booking system asks for full payment to be made via credit card, Afterpay or PayPal on booking. If you do not have access to these payment methods or need to pay your course fee over time please email us to arrange this
Course fee $280, Early bird pricing $252 till 27 July.

description:
Leadlight Glass - 4 Weeks Block, Learn to create gorgeous leadlight designs with our experienced jewellers! This great course runs from Friday 12 September for 4 weeks until Friday 3 October, 5.30pm - 8pm.

Your 4-week block will give you time to learn the basics and then create one or more leadlight projects.

This class is ideal for creating sun-catchers or small decorative projects for beginners, or working on slightly more complex pieces for those with some experience.

Beginners will start by planning their design, then learning to cut the glass, and prepare it before foiling and soldering each piece, creating a simple elegant clear glass starter project.

Beautiful coloured glass, copper foil and leadlight solder are then available to purchase as required for your other projects.

This is a warm and friendly class with excellent support and learning for complete beginners and more advanced students. All tools are supplied, though you are welcome to bring your own tools and glass if you have them.

Your materials for your beginner project are supplied as part of your course fee, extra materials will be available for purchase if you wish to make larger pieces or more than one project.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Knitting for Beginners, Always wanted to learn how to knit but never been sure where to begin? Join craft tutor Stella Carruthers as she teaches the basic principles of knitting in this fun, informative and supportive class. Come along and learn the essential building blocks of knitting, using only knitting needles, yarn and your hands!
Come and reap the benefits of a mindful and meditative craft-form. Meet other people interested in making things with their hands, chat over crafting and find out what the craft craze is all about.

Join crafter Stella as she shares her ten years plus knitting experience in this beginner’s knitting class that supports each student as an individual learner.

Master basic knitting techniques, learn how to cast stitches on and off the needles, explore the knit and purl stitches and practice how to hold the needles in a way that is comfortable for you - then learn how to knit in the English style.

Knitting needles and yarn are included in the course fee, but you're welcome to bring along your own 4-ply yarn if you wish.

By the end of the course you will have created two squares of knitting, one in basic garter stitch and the other utilising both knit and purl stitches to create the knitted fabric called stocking stitch.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Karanga taonga, karanga tangata, karanga whenua |Reversing Cultural Amnesia: Activating Māori Practice in Museums, In 1947, Māori leader, politician, and scholar Apirana Ngata spoke to his scholarly peers at the Polynesian Society, announcing his greatest desire to revive Māori culture as a living force within communities, not be relegated to dead exhibits in museums (Ramsden 1948, 85).
This lecture acknowledges the concerns of visionary leaders and champions of cultural practice and their activation within museums. Through her work as a Māori curator, writer, cultural practitioner and post-doctoral researcher, Awhina Tamarapa advocates for cultural restoration as a form of liberation in a museum context. In her research, Tamarapa is exploring strategies for the recovery and reclamation of taonga puoro (singing treasures) and karetao (animated storytellers) for new generations.
There are challenges regarding taonga held by overseas museums. Concepts such as keeping taonga warm, and mana taonga, recognises the connection and authority of descendants to their taonga, that underpin this work.
The focus on the reclamation of Indigenous practice has been bolstered by working with First Nations, Canada BC. Led by Professor Bryony Onciul, University of Exeter, UK, Tamarapa was privileged to be part of a research project “The Future of Indigenous Rights and Responsibilities: Ancestral governance, environmental stewardship, language revival, and cultural vibrancy” funded by the Arts and Humanities Research Council, UK.
_________
The Michael Volkerling Lecture series is a partnership event with the Museum and Heritage Studies programme at Te Herenga Waka | Victoria University of Wellington, National Services Te Paerangi and Te Papa Tongarewa. This annual public lecture series recognises the legacy of the late Dr Michael Volkerling who was one of the principal architects of New Zealand's cultural and creative sectors.

description:
All That Heaven Allows, Details
Directed by Douglas Sirk
Starring Rock Hudson, Jane Wyman
70th Anniversary

--- Cary Scott is a well-to-do widow gradually re-entering a social life amongst her mostly dull country club peers. Her only apparent enjoyment in life comes from weekend visits from her college-age children. Cary then meets a handsome younger man, Ron, who owns a small landscaping business. A follower of Henry David Thoreau's Walden, Ron enjoys a life focused on nature and is deliberately uninterested in the gossipy opinions of others. Their romance causes clashes and tensions between Cary, her children, and the country club. ---

This is a TEA TIME TALKIE screening where a delicious Devonshire Tea* awaits for upgraded tickets holders (a cup of tea and traditional homemade scones with cream and jam). This is served upstairs in the Grand Lobby during the intermission.

description:
Make Your Own Roman Blinds, Come along and learn how to make your very own Roman blind, to give your rooms an elegant and streamlined look.

Description
Roman blinds are a perennial favourite because they use a lot less fabric than the usual pencil pleated or gathered curtains - as well as making your rooms look streamlined and uncluttered.

During the four weeks you will learn how to accurately measure your window to enable you to create very own customized roman blind.

Some hardware included in course fee but a list of all other materials (fabric, etc) will be sent out to you when the course is confirmed.

Please choose a narrow window for your first project - max 150cms wide.

By the end of the course you'll be able to

Accurately measure your window
Calculate how much fabric to purchase
Measure and cut out your curtain
Use appropriate machine skills to sew your curtain fabric
Use finishing skills to apply rings and cords to your curtain
Identify appropriate method to hang Roman Blind

Matiu Te Huki Haka for life workshop - Moera Hall - Lower Hutt, You can pay online via bank deposit (if you don't want to use credit/debit card) using this account. $30
Please email matiuthehook@gmail.com with your details and a screen shot of the payment so I can secure your spot at the event
Matthew Te Huki
38-9003-0669210-00
Workshop starts at 1:30pm please be there by 1:15 ready to start on time
Haka for Life Workshop
🔥 Haka for life – A Transformational Māori Experience with Matiu 🔥
Step into a sacred, immersive journey led by Matiu—a master of Māori language, performance, and storytelling, with over 30 years of experience empowering individuals across the globe.
This dynamic, interactive workshop weaves together ancient Māori wisdom with modern empowerment, unlocking deep connection, strength, and presence like never before.
🌿 What You’ll Experience:
✔ The Warrior’s Energy – Harness the raw power of haka, the traditional Māori dance that awakens your inner fire and unshakable presence. ✔ The Art of Connection – Learn the profound practice of hongi, the sacred sharing of breath, and cultivate deeper relationships. ✔ The Power of Storytelling & Song – Discover the soul-stirring magic of Māori narrative and music. ✔ Sacred Masculine & Feminine Balance – Explore potent, healing practices that honor, empower, and connect on a deep, transformative level. ✔ Embracing Light & Shadow – Find balance between your strength and vulnerability, your power and grace.
⚡ Why This Workshop?
This is for those who are ready to step into their power. Those who want to speak with confidence, move with purpose, and lead with authenticity.
By the end of this experience, you will: ✅ Feel grounded, present, and connected—to yourself, to spirit, to your ancestors. ✅ Command a room with presence and mana (power) when you speak. ✅ Own your voice—so that people truly listen and feel your words. ✅ Stand in your warrior energy—unshakable, confident, and fully embodied. ✅ Walk away with practical, ancient tools to help you move through life with more strength, clarity, and purpose.
🔥 Are You Ready? 🔥
If you’re up for real growth, if you’re ready to step into your power, be seen, be heard, and be fully present—then this workshop is for YOU.
Matiu’s approach is welcoming, inspiring, fun, safe and deeply empowering.
🌿 Join us. Awaken your warrior. Change your life.
Here are testimonials for workshop:
Kia Ora. I felt new strength to be in integrity with myself and power to speak from this place within. The workshop was a beautiful experience of the love and trust that is possible in community - and
that resonated for ages and flowed into all my interactions moving through life. When are you coming back to Hobart, Matiu, to do more workshops?
Here is another testimonial from Bali spirit fest participant:
It's not often in life, that I've met someone so powerfully walking their talk, that by their presence alone they can offer a deep transformational experience. I have felt this on both the occasions I've had the pleasure to cross Matiu's path. He has an ability to hold space and guide an opening and understanding of the moment, and the current times. Of divine male/female divide, and the healing available to individuals and our collective. I would highly recommend engaging with him on any level, it's definitely been a rewarding and growth promoting experience in my journey.

description:
Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami, Māori, Christianity & the Spirit World — Public lecture by Bradford Haami
In lecture theatre 2 (GBLT2) in the Law School at Victoria University / Te Herenga Waka.

Ramsey Library presents a public lecture by Bradford Haami.

What happens when vastly different ways of being meet? Dame Anne Salmond writes of ‘competing cosmologies’ and ‘ontological collisions’ — European missionaries arriving in Aotearoa in the early 19th century brought a Biblical cosmology that began such a collision. In this public lecture Bradford Haami will explore the interactions between Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual worldviews that continue to evolve up to the present.

* How do Biblical and Māori cultural and spiritual beliefs and thought relate?
* How 19th century rangatira negotiate between traditional beliefs and the Biblical narratives?
* Where do Christian and Māori ways of knowing and seeing clash, compete or enrich each other?
* What does being Māori and Christian look like today?


Bradford Haami (Ngāti Awa) is a Māori historian, researcher and author with research interests in Māori worldviews, spirituality, Christianity and cultural preservation. He is Pou Amorangi (Māori Director) at Laidlaw College in Auckland, New Zealand, where he lectures in biculturalism and sits on the governing board of the college. Haami has written several books on Māori history, culture and spirituality, with recent works including Urban Māori: The Second Great Migration (Oratia Media 2018) and Bringing Culture into Care (Huia 2019). He was the Māori curator/expert on the acclaimed Te Taiao / Nature exhibition at Te Papa Tongarewa Museum.

--
To browse the Ramsey Library catalogue, and sign up to borrow books (free), go to https://library.chaplaincyvuw.org.nz

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
(door sales will be available)
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/

description:
PADI Advanced Open Water Course, PADI Advanced Open Water Course
“Your Next Step in Underwater Adventure”
Exploration excitement and experiences are what the PADI Advanced Open Water
course is all about. And no you don't have to be "advanced" to take it - it's designed
so both new and experienced Open Water Divers can sign up and develop better
diving skills and techniques straight away!

The Advanced Open Water Diver course helps you increase your confidence and
build scuba skills to become safer and more comfortable in the water. It’s also a great
way to get more diving experience under the supervision of a PADI Instructor.
This course builds on what you've learnt and develops new capabilities by
introducing new dive activities and ways to have fun scuba diving. You will complete
5 different types of dives to build your confidence and develop your dive skills. The
dives include the basics of Deep Diving Underwater Navigation - and your choice of
Peak Performance Buoyancy Naturalist Fish Identification Wreck (weather dependant)
Enriched Air * Photography or Night during winter.

Complete the theory online then join us for a weekends diving. After the 5 dives
over the weekend you will qualify as a PADI Advanced Open Water Diver. This is the
minimum requirement for many of our dive adventures and a prerequisite for the
PADI Rescue Diver course.

If you have any questions please call so we can help you.

description:
Padi Advanced Open Water Course, Exploration, excitement and experiences are what the PADI Advanced Open Water (AOW) Diver course is all about.

The AOW course is designed for both new and more experienced Open Water Divers and is best attended as soon after your Open Water Diver course as possible. That way you will increase your confidence and build scuba skills to become safer and more comfortable in the water; all under the supervision of a PADI Instructor.

The AOW course consists of five dives that includes a: Deep and an Underwater Navigation dive. Popular local options for the remaining three dives are: Peak Performance Buoyancy, Naturalist, Wreck, Fish Identification, Imaging, Night, *Enriched Air or *Dive Against Debris (* conditions apply).

You may choose to add the 'Enriched Air' and/or the 'Dive Against Debris' specialty qualifications to your weekend experience. Simply ask to: include these dives as part of your five dives, complete the on-line study and a short practical, pay a small fee – and go diving. These Specialties count towards the prestigious PADI Master Scuba Diver rating.

Pay your deposit and you can begin the AOW theory. Make sure your dive medical is current, then join us for a weekend's fun diving. After everything is completed, you will qualify as a PADI AOW Diver. This is the minimum requirement for our dive adventures and a prerequisite for the PADI Rescue Diver course.
If you have any questions, please call so we can help you.

description:
Paraparaumu Makeup Masterclass - 21.09 @9.15 am, About this event
Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.
During the class, Nikki will demonstrate step-by-step techniques on a model while you get to apply your own makeup. You'll have access to professional products and tools to follow along and create your flawless everyday look. It’s fun, interactive, and designed for all skill levels.
"I can’t wait to share my knowledge with you and help you create a makeup routine that leaves you feeling fabulous and confident every day!" – Nikki
What You Need to Know:
No equipment required! We’ll provide all makeup products, brushes, and mirrors.
Bring a willingness to learn and a positive attitude.
Classes are capped at 12-15 participants to ensure personalised guidance.
Arrive 10–15 minutes early to get settled.
Please come with a clean, makeup-free face so you can get the best results.

description:
Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna, Wearable Stories: Bolo Tie & Sheriff Badge Making with Keri-Mei Zagrobelna
In this hands-on workshop, participants will transform upcycled drink cans into unique wearable pieces — bolo ties or sheriff badges — inspired by Keri-Mei Zagrobelna's work in the exhibition Flaming Star. Using accessible, low-tech techniques, you’ll explore design, embossing, and enamel painting to create a piece you can take home and wear with pride.

Register at

What You’ll Learn:

The cultural background and kaupapa behind bolo ties and sheriff badges.

How to design and plan a wearable artwork.

Techniques for prepping and embossing tin.

How to transfer a design to metal and finish it with enamel paint.

Simple methods to attach your design to a bolo tie or badge backing.

What’s Provided:
All materials, including prepped tin from recycled drink cans, tools, paints, and bolo tie/badge fittings.

What to Bring:
An open mind, a steady hand, and any personal imagery or patterns you’d like to incorporate into your design.

Who This Workshop is For:
No experience necessary — perfect for beginners and those wanting to try creative metalwork in an accessible, fun way.

description:
Paediatrics: Daytime Mobility & Function + Practical Workshop (Wellington), Paediatric Academy Wellington - Venue to be announced
_____________________________________________________________________________________________
Overview:
Join us for an engaging and interactive session focused on paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) and safe car seat solutions! We’ll explore prescribing AT for sitting, standing, stepping, and mobility—blending clinical theory with real-world insights on equipment choices.
Engage in a hands-on practical session to test techniques, plus learn how to collaborate with parents, caregivers, and kids for practical, daily-use solutions, including safe transportation. Don’t miss this chance to boost your skills and confidence!
Learning Objectives
Identify and describe different types of paediatric Assistive Technology (AT) equipment
Explain the clinical rationale behind equipment prescription
Enhance collaboration with families and caregivers
Assess the functional needs of children and recommend suitable AT solutions
About our Presentor:
Jamie's Bio:
BSc Physiotheraop, Paediatric Product Education - Medifab
Jamie Cockle is a trained physiotherapist and Medifab's Paediatric Clinical Educator and Seating and Positioning Specialist. With a passion for empowering therapists, product specialists, and families, Jamie provides expert training on Medifab’s paediatric equipment, ensuring practical knowledge that can be applied every day to optimise children’s health and happiness.
Jamie’s career began as a Paediatric Physiotherapist at Noah’s Ark Children’s Hospital in Cardiff, followed by a role at Bristol Royal Hospital for Children. It was in these settings that he developed his expertise in paediatric equipment, particularly for children with neurological conditions. He is driven by the belief that every child should have access to the right support, regardless of their abilities or diagnosis..

description:
Sculpture - Intro to Creature Sculpting, Join us in an exciting new introduction to creative sculpting - a hands on class to produce unique creature figurines and miniatures to bring your imagination to life! - Beginners welcome! All material costs included in course fee.

Description
Whether you want to make creatures cute, creepy, in the style of pop-toys, figurines, or a one-of-a-kind character in your own style, this is the class for you!

Working with air dry clays, oven bake polymer clays and wire, armatures this workshop offers a variety of modelling methods and approaches - a great opportunity to turn ideas into tangible 3D forms. With modern clays we can create translucent, flexible, and even glow-in-the-dark elements to add more realism or a touch of the surreal into each creation!

We’ll kick off working with traditional air-dry clay to get a feel for modelling a few simple forms.

Once familiar with the materials, we’ll go through some basic design elements, guided by animal anatomy and morphology. From here the tutor will show and chat with the group about ways we can transform the creatures from our imagination into unique sculptures full of character.

Students will be coached through designing and creating a series of small-scale creature sculptures, beginning simple, and building to a more complex final form as we gather practice.

The class offers beginner students a fun introduction to sculpting organic forms from scratch, and for those with some hands-on creative experience, it offers a great opportunity to experiment, hone and advance your making skills to new levels.

Please wear closed-in footwear suitable for a workshop environment. bring a work apron if you have one or wear clothes you don’t mind getting a little grubby. Remember to bring your reading glasses if a have them.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

description:
Secure Development Training - September 2025, Have you been to a Kawaiicon and found yourself realising that you want to know more? Are you a curious developer who wants to know what happens if you prod a web application? Are you a QA looking to take the worst path possible through an app?
Maybe the PrivSec Secure Development Training is for you!
Agenda
The training is a one day course consisting of the following:
A detailed overview of the OWASP Top Ten Web Application vulnerabilities.
Multiple real world examples and case studies of exploited vulnerabilities.
Hands on experience exploiting these vulnerabilities on a custom web application
Techniques and tooling to identify and exploit these bug classes, using both source code analysis and dynamic testing techniques.
Remediation steps and techniques to mitigate and avoid these issues.
Outcomes
By the end of the day, you will have an understanding of tools and techniques used to compromise web applications and hands on experience in exploiting multiple vulnerabilities in the OWASP top ten.
About the Trainer
Training will be led by one of our Senior consultants, Jack Moran and supported by Sriram Jayaraman
Jack is a Senior Consultant at PrivSec Consulting. He has worked in the offensive security space for the better part of a decade, focusing on web and mobile application testing, along with code reviews and security configuration reviews. He has a number of CVEs credited to himself, and his enthusiasm towards security security is infectious.
Sriram is an ex-developer, turned security consultant. He has a strong background in web application penetration testing, along with code review. He has familiarity with several programming and scripting languages and frameworks such as Python, Javascript, PHP, Node.js, Angular and React.
Notes for the Day
Lunch and snacks will be provided. We will teach you how to hack.

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene and GIB.
CPD points: 10
TIMING:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
LECTURE DATES:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre
Tāhuna Queenstown | Friday 5 September | Crowne Plaza
Whakatū Nelson | Tuesday 9 September | The Suter - Te Aratoi o Whakatū
Ōtautahi Christchurch | Wednesday 10 September | Black Box Theatre - Papa Hou
Heretaunga Hastings | Thursday 11 September | Toi Toi
Ngāmotu New Plymouth | Monday 15 September | Novotel
Kirikiriroa Hamilton | Tuesday 16 September | Bill Gallagher Centre
Tāmaki Makaurua Auckland | Thursday 18 September | TBC

description:
Return to Babylon Documentary Film Screening, The Assyrian Church of the East Youth Association (ACEYA) (Wellington Branch) is excited to present a special screening of 'Return to Babylon'—the only one of its kind in Aotearoa New Zealand.
The documentary film takes you on an Assyrian family’s journey as they visit the Assyrian Homeland after years of living in France.
This is a story of reconnecting with one’s roots, identity, and people.
Following the screening, we will have a pre-recorded Q&A session which includes the film's director, Sébastien Daycard-Heid, and Sémiramis Ide and Agnes Ide Banipal—two of the film's protagonists.
 Synopsis:
Sémiramis is French, an Eastern Christian, and Assyro-Chaldean. In the Val-d'Oise region, this community, originally from Turkey and Iraq, has lived since the 1980s in a rhythm marked by weddings, church services, and family meals.
Shaped by the exile of their parents and the persecution their community faced under the Turkish dictatorship and Daesh, Sémiramis nurtures her roots in Assyrian civilization, originating from Mesopotamia. But the puzzle of her history no longer fits together as it once did.
Gradually, the elders are disappearing, taking with them an identity and culture that is 6,000 years old. How can this fracture be repaired, and this heritage preserved? Should they consider staying or returning to their ancestral homeland, now that peace has returned? Can one go back after decades of conflict? Can they rebuild and start anew to live in peace with themselves and others?
"Return to Babylon" is a road movie from Sarcelles to Erbil, following Sémiramis and her family on a journey that leads them to question their future in France and the fate of their community in the Middle East.
A film by Marie Dault, Sémiramis Ide, and Sébastien Daycard-Heid
Directed by Sébastien Daycard-Heid
Screen time: 52-minutes; French and Assyrian with subtitles
Link to the English-subtitled trailer: https://www.instagram.com/p/DDzsYJzt_B9/
The screening event will be held at the Cockburn Street Chapel, 1 Cockburn Street, Kilbirnie, Wellington from 5-7pm.

Entrance is free, but please register to confirm your attendance.

We welcome koha (donations) which will go towards supporting the ACEYA Wellington Branch's youth-focused activities and events.

description:
STEAMS School BLENHEIM Term 4 2025, What is STEAMS?
STEAMS is an integrated learning programme covering Science, Technology, Engineering, Arts, Maths, and Society. It focuses on real-world skills, critical thinking, collaboration, and creativity through hands-on, project-based learning—not play-based, but purposeful exploration without rigid time constraints.
Students are immersed in engaging, age-appropriate activities that encourage curiosity, innovation, and independent learning.
Key Benefits:
Students in STEAMS learn to:
Think creatively and critically
Collaborate and communicate effectively
Connect ideas across disciplines
Take ownership of their learning
Explore without pressure
Understand real-world applications
When & Where?
Weekly classes during school terms, based on age group and location:
Blenheim-Waterlea Racecourse
Class Times:
Little STEAMerS (Ages 5–6): TUES 11:30am–2:45pm
STEAMS Jr (Ages 7–9): TUES 9:00am–2:45pm
STEAMS Sr (Ages 10–13): THURS 9:00am–2:45pm
Cost
Trial (3 weeks): Pay via Humanitix (non-refundable)
Ongoing: $75/day (incl. GST)
Little STEAMerS: $30/day
Scholarships: 25% off for financial need (not available for Little STEAMerS)
School Absence?
Inform your child’s regular school—they’re attending STEAMS School. Most schools are supportive, and students should be marked as justified.

description:
Spring Container Planting Workshop, Grow Your Own Kai - In Containers From Your Own Compost

Want to grow your own fresh kai but only have a balcony, patio, or courtyard? This hands-on workshop will show you how to grow spring vegetables and herbs in containers - a flexible, low-cost way to turn even the smallest space into a productive garden. Following on from our winter edition, this is the second workshop in our seasonal container growing series, with a focus on getting your spring garden thriving using your own compost.

This workshop will cover:
- What to grow in spring, including leafy greens, herbs, and root vegetables
- How to set up containers - choosing the right size, drainage, potting mix, and using your own compost or bokashi soil
- Feeding your plants with DIY fertilisers, spotting nutrient gaps, and refreshing tired soil
- Creating ideal growing conditions with sunlight, watering tips, wind protection, and natural pest control
- Keeping your garden productive by harvesting, replanting, and rotating crops throughout the season

Please bring your own container(s) - buckets, storage bins, flexi tubs, or old drawers all welcome. We will show you how to safely repurpose them.

Spaces are limited, book now to get growing this Spring!

description:
Sterling Silver Earring Workshop, Sterling Silver Earring Workshop
Make your own Sterling Silver summer earrings – Saturday 13th September at Square Edge Art Centre, Palmerston North

Looking for a fun workshop to get your creative juices flowing after a long week in the office? Then come join us on Saturday 13th September at the Square Edge Art Centre in Palmerston North where you will make your own pair of sterling silver earrings in 4 – 5 hours.

When: Saturday 13th September, starts at 10:00 for about 4 – 5 hours (or until you’re done)
Cost: $120 - $150 pp (depending on if you add a gemstone to your design or not. See more info below)
Space: Only 8 spaces available ( book at https://www.rholenesingleton.com/product-page/summer-earrings-workshop )


What to expect:
• Friendly, expert guidance by local metalsmith Rholene Singleton. She will assist you every step of the way ensuring you leave with a beautiful pair of earrings at the end of the day.
• Design your own earrings to create something uniquely yours, or make use of the templates available, which you can embellish as you like.
• You have the option to add a semi-precious cabochon gemstone to your design.
• A selection of refreshments will be available, but you are welcome to bring a light lunch if you feel like the day will get too long without it.
• Relaxed and fun morning enjoyed in the beautiful iconic Square Edge Art Centre in the heart of Palmerston North. View the current artist exhibitions currently on show in the center for free.


Practical Details:
Come and learn the ancient art of silver jewellery making through demonstrations and then giving it a go yourself while you create your own beautiful new summer earrings, using a jewellers saw, blowtorch, gemstone setting tools and more.

• Two options for this workshop:
1. Plain sterling silver earrings - $120 pp
2. Add cabochon gemstones to your design - $150 pp

• 4 – 5 hours of guidance as you create your own piece
• All tools and materials included
• A selection of gemstones to choose from

Your space will be confirmed once payment is received. This workshop is first come, first serve. Space is limited.

To book please go to https://www.rholenesingleton.com/product-page/summer-earrings-workshop

description:
Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture 2025 | Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects are excited to welcome Ian Moore to New Zealand to present this year’s lecture series ‘The Past Needs a Future’ which will focus on adaptive reuse.
Ian is the principal of Ian Moore Architects, established in 1990. The practice has won numerous Australian and international awards and has been published and exhibited widely, including at the Venice Architecture Biennale in 2008 and 2012.
Initially studying civil and structural engineering at the Auckland Technical Institute in New Zealand, Ian moved on to study architecture at the University of Technology, Sydney, graduating with honours in 1988.
Ian has taught at numerous universities and been a speaker and guest lecturer throughout Australia as well as internationally.
Ian has also been a member of awards juries in Australia, New Zealand and at the World Festival of Interiors in 2013 and the World Architecture Festival in 2015. In 2003, Ian was the inaugural Creative Director for the Australian Institute of Architects annual conference.
About the Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture
The annual Sir Ian Athfield Memorial Lecture commemorates the late Ian Athfield, a singular and much-loved figure in New Zealand architecture.
Affectionately known as ‘Ath’, Ian was knighted in 2014 and was one of New Zealand’s most influential architects. He won more than 60 national and international architecture and design awards and the lecture series was established to honour his legacy and celebrate his larrikin spirit.
In keeping with that spirit, each year the lecture is given by a person with something to say – someone who is challenging orthodoxy and a business-as-usual approach to practice, and life.
During his career, Ath designed many significant buildings, none more so than his own home in Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington, which enraged the neighbours, perplexed the Council and inspired the city for decades.
Ath was talented, original, insightful, opinionated, provocative, and sometimes outrageous. His architecture is stimulating, challenging, ever-changing, but never careless.
In 2004, Te Kāhui Whaihanga New Zealand Institute of Architects awarded Ath the Gold Medal for career achievements, noting at the time “What defines Athfield above all is his contagious enthusiasm, his devotion to architecture, and his unswerving belief in its possibilities. Believing architecture to be a civilising force, he has demonstrated a strong commitment to architecture’s public realm: the streets we live in; the urban centres we inhabit; the countryside we love and so often abuse.”
The Sir Ian Athfield Lecture Series is proudly sponsored by Resene and GIB.
CPD points: 10
TIMING:
Doors open: 5.00pm
Lecture: 5.30pm - 6.30pm
Q&A: 6.30pm - 7.00pm
LECTURE DATES:
Te Whanganui-a-Tara Wellington | Wednesday 3 September | Michael Fowler Centre
Tāhuna Queenstown | Friday 5 September | Crowne Plaza
Whakatū Nelson | Tuesday 9 September | The Suter - Te Aratoi o Whakatū
Ōtautahi Christchurch | Wednesday 10 September | Black Box Theatre - Papa Hou
Heretaunga Hastings | Thursday 11 September | Toi Toi
Ngāmotu New Plymouth | Monday 15 September | Novotel
Kirikiriroa Hamilton | Tuesday 16 September | Bill Gallagher Centre
Tāmaki Makaurua Auckland | Thursday 18 September | TBC

description:
Saturday Laughs with Michael Macaulay and Lana Walters, Saturday Laughs is a comedy showcase with top Kiwi comedians from around the country, right in the heart of Wellington at Fringe Bar!

This month features headline act Lana Walters
Winner of the Billy T award, Lana is a fabulous standup comedian, television writer and improviser. A regular panelist on 7Days and The Project, you may have also seen her in the Best Foods Comedy Gala or The Great Comedy Debate. As well as all this, Lana is a mum of two young kids giving her endless material and sleepless nights.

With MC Michael Macaulay
Michael started in comedy in the late 90s, eventually winning the Becks Beer award for Best Newcomer at the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2001. After a nearly 20 year hiatus he returned to comedy in a totally different country and having learned no life lessons at all.
Since then he has twice been nominated for ‘Best MC’, in the Welly Awards; won his own Welly in 2020 for being an all-round nice person; and performs up and down Aotearoa.

Also featuring
Gabby Anderson
Ralph Hilaga
and more!
label: Arts & Theatre

description:
The Art of Mending - Micro Mill, When it comes to the clothes we love, every rip, stain, and imperfection is an invitation to exercise agency, expression, and an opportunity to show the garment how much we appreciate it.

This class is cared for by the whimsical Aisha, a multidisciplinary artist with a passion for empowering the mending process. Each month on Wednesday evenings Aisha will introduce us to a different technique for reviving our beloved textile pieces. If you're like us and have a box of clothing in need of repairs that never seems to empty... this is the club for you. With three events a month we'll inspire each other to creatively care for those pieces we love! This club is also perfect for anyone who loves learning new skills. Techniques we'll cover are lino printing, patching, darning, felting, embroidery, beading, sashiko, fabric painting and more! All materials and tools are supplied at each class - but you are welcome to bring your own. We highly encourage bringing those clothes or other textile items that need some love and repair.

There is no need to attend every class. We can catch you up on the skill at which ever class you choose to join us at. There are single class tickets or monthly sign ups available. Both of these have variable pricing options, unwaged/student, waged, and generous. Please choose whichever option feels right for you and your circumstances!

In August we are Lino Printing!
Class 02: 20th August
At this class Aisha will take us through the process of designing and cutting our own lino to print with! You're welcome to keep going with the pre cut designs as well. Lino and carving tools will be supplied.

Class 03: 27th August
This class will be open to what you want to work on! Bring in larger project items, print with the lino cuts you made in the previous week, or cut some fresh ones!

In September we are patching!
Class 01: 10th September
Aisha will take us through the process of sewing on patches. Patches that we printed in the August classes will be available for this. You're welcome to bring your own patches as well. Please bring something that needs a patch up or a little bit of decoration.

Class 02: 17th September
At this class we will learn how to appliqué, the process of using scrap fabric to make decorative patches. This is a great way to elevate a rip or stain with some visible mending.

Class 03: 24th September
At this last class of the month we'll be open for all the patching needs. Hang out and finish projects we've started or mend some extra items.

Be sure to check our website or here for updates about techniques coming up in the following months.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1, This course is for beginners who have no prior knowledge of te reo Māori or Māori culture. (NZ Citizens and residents pay $109 with ID, all others pay $199).

Description
Te Reo Māori - Introductory 1

By the end of the course, you’ll be able to:

• Have a basic understanding of the Māori spiritual and natural worlds (mana atua, mana whenua), and our important connections to them
• Identify the sounds of Māori letters and pronounce letter combinations using correct intonation and stress patterns
• Confidently greet people, introduce yourself and communicate basic personal information in an informal context
• Identify and respond to phrases in the classroom including basic commands/instructions
• Confidently describe the day/date, time, and the weather

NOTE: This course is subsidised with funding from the Tertiary Education Commission (TEC) and you must provide photo ID when you attend your first session, if applicable.

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
Mystery Feast on Mischief Night! Halloween dinner with Chef Max Gordy 🎃 Supporting Kaibosh., Mystery Feast on Mischief Night! Halloween dinner with Chef Max Gordy 🎃 Supporting Kaibosh.
🎃 Step inside, if you dare... on the eve of Halloween. It's a Mischief Night!
👻A chilling murder mystery unfolds over a hauntingly good three-course Halloween dinner by Chef Max Gordy!

On 30 October, gather your cleverest friends and find your darkest ghoulish attire 🧛‍♀️ Who will crack the case first: the Detectives or the Villains? 🕵️‍♂️
Expect twists, laughter, and a touch of fright 💀 with spot prizes through the night — plus a reward for the best-dressed.

👩‍🍳 Award-winning chef Max Gordy ( @grazewinebar ) will conjure up a frightfully delicious Halloween-themed feast.
🥂 Your ticket includes one complimentary alcoholic beverage (with more available to purchase on the night).
🙌 Every ticket sold helps Kaibosh ensure that no good food is left to die.

TICKET TYPES
Bring a team of six to solve the mystery and devour a fiendishly good feast for $666.
Have a frightening four-some? Book a table for $444.
Spooky single seats available for $111... we will seat you at a mystery table...

VENUE
60 Dixon Street is up a flight of steep steps – with only one way in.

What is Mischief Night?
In parts of Pennsylvania and New Jersey in the eastern USA, 30 October is called “Mischief Night.” The tradition refers to the eve of Halloween in which children and teenagers celebrate the holiday one night early with pranks, tricks and more. While in New England, some call it Cabbage Night...
Join us to experience Chef Max Gordy's culinary take on Mischief Night in Pōneke!

#Halloween #HalloweenNZ #MischiefNight #MaxGordy #EveybodyEats #CharityDinner #FundraisingDinner #WellingtonDining #Pōneke #WellingtonNZ
label: Food & Drink

Careers Without Borders 2025, 🗓️ When: 5:30-8:00pm, Wednesday 17 September 
📍 Where: RHLH1, Rutherford House, Pipitea Campus
The event will run as follows:
5:30–5:40 pm: Opening Remarks
5:40–6:10 pm: MFAT Panel
6:20–6:50 pm: Breakout Session 1 (choice of 3 panels)
7:00–7:30 pm: Breakout Session 2 (choice of 3 panels)
7:30–8:00 pm: Light Catering & Networking 🍕
Following the MFAT panel, the three specialised panels from which students can choose to attend two include: Trade & Commerce, International Development, and Defence & Security.
The following are our confirmed speakers for each panel:
MFAT: James Lester (Senior Policy Officer, Middle East & Africa Division; former WTO posting, Trade Law Adviser), Thandiwe Keet (Niue Desk Officer; previously NZ-UKFTA & IPETCA roles), and Anya Donohue (Deputy Secretary’s Office, Pacific & Development Group).
Trade & Commerce: Ailish Dodd and Brenna Burch (Wellington Chamber of Commerce, International Engagement Officers), Phil Quinn (MBIE, International Trade Negotiator), and Gregor Thompson (Business Desk, Economic Affairs Writer).
International Development: Peter Scott (Former Disaster Management Delegate to Tonga; current Pacific Programmes Lead). Additional speakers TBC.
Defence & Security: Ministry of Defence representative and Kevin Moar (Director of National Security Policy, DPMC). Additional speakers TBC.

description:
ECD Emotional Leadership Development Course 20th November - Central Wellington, ECD Emotional Leadership Development 1 Day Certification Course
Become a Certified Emotional Culture Deck Leadership Practitioner
This course is designed to enhance leadership development by equipping leaders with the tools to understand and manage emotional drivers and dynamics within themselves, their people and their teams. The course focuses on developing emotionally aware leaders who can effectively foster a positive workplace culture. Participants will engage in practical activities that promote self-awareness, team cohesion, and emotional intelligence, all grounded in The Emotional Culture Deck framework.
"Emotional culture is shaped by how all employees—from the highest echelons to the front lines—comport themselves day in and day out. But it’s up to senior leaders to establish which emotions will help the organization thrive, model those emotions, and reward others for doing the same. Companies in which they do this have a lot to gain." – Sigal Barsade & Olivia O'Neil, Manage Your Emotional Culture

Why this course is a Game-Changer

In today’s fast-paced and complex business environment, the ability to lead with emotion is more critical than ever. Our ECD Emotional Leadership Development Course is designed to transform the way leaders understand and harness the power of emotions to foster a more dynamic and responsive workplace.
What to expect
This hands-on one-day course is designed for immediate application, ensuring that you can translate insights into action as soon as you return to your team or clients. 
What to expect from this 1 day course experience:
Understanding the power of emotions in leading others effectively
Development of effective emotion-led leadership strategies. 
Learning how to use and embed our ready-made Emotional Culture Deck Leadership Tools
Active learning through interactive activities and group discussions.
Exploration of personal leadership and team leadership.
What's included in this course?
Enrol in the ECD Emotional Leadership Development Course and unlock a wealth of resources including:
ECD Emotional Leadership Development Toolkit - Valued at 175 NZD: Get this invaluable toolkit filled with a robust selection of physical and downloadable resources designed for immediate impact. Its comprehensive nature will extend your learning and application of the course content well beyond the Course.
1x Emotional Culture Deck  - Valued at 155 NZD: Receive your personal ECD, an essential tool for applying courseprinciples in real-world settings, adding even more value to your toolkit.
Exclusive 60-Minute Group Coaching Call: Enhance your course experience with a group coaching call, scheduled six to eight weeks post-course. Hosted via Zoom, this session provides an opportunity to solidify your learning, address any questions, and ensure you're applying your new skills effectively. Whether you attend live or watch the replay later, this call is a key step in your continued development.
Continued Learning Discount: Enjoy a 50% discount on future purchases of The Emotional Culture Deck to support your ongoing practice.
ECD Emotional Leadership Certificate of Practice: A formal acknowledgement of your dedication to enhancing your Emotional Culture Deck skills. This certificate serves as a testament to your commitment to emotional leadership and amplifying human conversations about what really matters in the workplace
90-Day All Access Pass to our Online Elephant Rider Community: By enrolling, you gain access to an ECD Emotional Leadership package with resources, expertise, and continued support, all designed to flip the traditional approach to leadership development
Gain access to an ECD Emotional Leadership package with resources, expertise, and continued support, all designed to flip the traditional approach to leadership development.



Is this course right for you?
This course is great for executives, leaders and managers within organisations as well as those who consult or coach on leadership, culture and emotional intelligence. 
The course is ideal for:
HR Professionals: Who aim to enhance leadership qualities and traits and train their leaders to develop emotional intelligence within the workplace.
Leadership Coaches: Dedicated to developing emotionally smart leadership practices in diverse environments.
Organisation Development Managers: Focused on building adaptable, resilient organisational cultures through effective leadership.
Coaches and Consultants: Specialising in personal and professional and personal leadership development.
Project Leaders: Committed to managing project teams with empathy and emotional insight.
Team Leads and Supervisors: Looking to improve team cohesion and performance through emotional awareness.
Aspiring and experienced leaders: You could be a developing leader OR if you are an experienced leader who wants to develop in the emotional leadership space then this course is for you.
Whether you are leading initiatives within your organisation or providing expert advice to others, the Emotional Leadership Development Course provides the tools and insights necessary to develop more effective, emotionally aware leaders and teams.
What previous participants had to say about this workshop.
10/10 - "Giving everyone regardless of their emotional literacy a way to express themselves and to form authentic connections is genius! Learning how to use this to help teams and organisations change their emotional culture in an intentional way is super exciting! Lotty was an amazing facilitator. Her energy and passion were 100% contagious. Her approach gentle and inclusive. I’d do it again in a heartbeat!" - Cordula Plassmann
9/10 - "This course opened my eyes to how emotions can be surfaced and navigated in leadership. A key takeaway was that we all have emotions, it's how we surface and leverage them." - Julia Anderson
10/10 - "A wonderful investment! Highly recommend this course to anyone looking to strengthen their collaboration and people leadership skills. Great fun, very practical and helpful tools to use in a wide variety of situations." - Rosaleen Smith
10/10 - "This course was truly inspiring and deeply motivating. Its mission to rehumanise workplaces and life really resonates with me and I’m excited to put these learnings into action.  Lotty was amazing - She has a very special way of explaining things. I was massively inspired and very empowered." - Phoebe Edge
10/10 - "Lotty was (and is) amazing, the size of the group was perfect for me, the amount of content and the explanations of how and when to use them was explicit, doing an in-person workshop was so much more useful to me personally. I've gained a load more confidence and I am excited to share what I learned." - Kelley Oliver
10/10 - "Extremely meaningful and engaging - a wonderful opportunity to first look internally at how I lead myself in order to focus on and improve how I achieve and support effective emotional leadership of my team." - Karinna McDonald
10/10 - "Absolutely loved it. I now feel informed and equipped to facilitate emotional culture conversations and workshops. Such important and powerful stuff - I believe every leader should know about and understand the difference between cognitive and emotional culture, in order to enable a truly thriving workforce. Lotty is an incredible facilitator - bringing energy, insight, kindness, and passion" - Teressa Betty
What is the Emotional Culture Deck?

The Emotional Culture Deck (ECD) is the number one game in the world for better workplace culture designed and created by Jeremy Dean of riders&elephants.
The ECD is currently used by over 400,000 people in over 55+ countries, it is a uniquely powerful way to create human conversations about what really matters in the workplace. 
The game facilitates face-to-face human conversations about what matters. It nudges vulnerability. Builds empathy. Creates connections and fosters trust within teams.
It's the ultimate card game toolkit for more successful and human workplaces.
Click here to learn more about The ECD and watch the origin story video below of the founder of riders&elephants sharing the story behind the game.
Join Lotty and learn how to use the Emotional Culture Deck to enhance your leadership
Learn from one of the worlds most experienced Emotional Culture Deck Consultants and Facilitators - Lotty Roberts, Founder of MiND.U, Master Elephant Rider and Certified ECD consultant .
Lotty Roberts is an Emotional Culture Coach, Consultant and Facilitator. Since completing the ECD Masterclass Course in 2018, Lotty has become one of the most experienced Emotional Culture Deck consultants in the world and the first to ever become a Master Level Certified ECD Consultant. Lotty has delivered over 200 Emotional Culture Deck client workshops, as well as dozens of 1:2:1's, helping teams of all sizes, in a variety of industries create more healthy and high performing cultures. 
Lotty is also a regular on the speaking circuit delivering talks and presentations on all aspects of emotional culture including change, leadership and resilience.
Lotty's speciality and passion is all about helping leaders, teams and cultures to thrive, flourish and flow in a fast paced world, through the power of mindfulness and embracing emotions.
Lotty is the founder of her business, ‘MiND.U’, where she is devoted to helping companies and individuals build the emotional capability, resilience and wisdom to navigate the ever changing, complex and dynamic world we find ourselves in.
Will refreshments be provided during the workshop?
Coffee, tea, water and some light snacks will be available during the morning tea break but you will need to bring or buy your own lunch.
What's the refund and cancellation policy?
Unfortunately, ECD Certified Consultants don’t offer refunds for this workshop experience. 
However, you may send someone else in your place to this workshop if you cannot attend for any reason.
You must notify your Workshop host that you will not attend the workshop and the name of the person that will attend in your spot.
If you cannot attend the workshop, and no one attends in your place, the workshop organiser will post your ECD Emotional Leadership Development Workshop Kit to you (Value 330 NZD) – so you don’t miss out completely.
If the Workshop Host cancels this workshop, you will be transferred to the next available workshop. You can contact the Workshop host for a refund if you cannot attend the revised workshop date.

description:
Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025, Wellington Foraging Workshop 14th September 2025
Join expert forager Felicity Joy of Wild Botanica for a comprehensive Wild Edible Weeds Foraging Workshop in the beautiful community gardens of Mount Victoria, Wellington.

This inspiring experience will open your eyes to the abundance of edible wild plants growing right under your nose.

We’ll unlock the secrets of foraging, connecting with the land, and turning humble "weeds" into delicious, nourishing food. You’ll gain confidence in identifying common edible plants, learn their botanical names, and understand their medicinal and nutritional benefits. We’ll also explore ethical foraging practices, how to spot toxic lookalikes, and share simple, practical ways to incorporate wild foods into your daily meals.

This isn’t just about food: it’s about sustainability, resilience, and reconnecting with the environment in a meaningful way. You'll leave with a deeper appreciation for the land, new skills to support local food security, and the knowledge to make your own simple meals from wild ingredients.

Class sizes are limited, so book early to secure your spot.
For more details and bookings, visit

www.wildbotanica.co.nz
follow @wild.botanica.nz on social media.

For questions, email .

Join my email newsletter to hear about upcoming foraging workshops: https://www.wildbotanica.co.nz/pages/newsletter

description:
Water Casting - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.
Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.
You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.
Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!
We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.
The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.
A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.
This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.
For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.
Workshop fee $128, Early bird $115 till 17 August.

Join Nikki, a Professional Makeup Artist & Colour Expert with over 14 years of experience, for an engaging and practical Makeup Masterclass. Nikki and her team focus on enhancing natural beauty and making makeup easy for everyone.
As we journey through life, our skin and style evolve. The best way to update your look and learn techniques that suit your unique face shape, style, and colouring is to attend one of our masterclasses. Whether you're a performer on stage, a busy professional, or a multitasking mum, this class will teach you how to apply your makeup quickly, flawlessly, and with confidence.

description:
Whāia te mātauranga hei oranga mō koutou: A Review, Nau mai, haere mai, hoki mai.
Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum is proud to present the Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum Legal Series, an informative lecture series about the purpose, historical significance and ongoing mahi of the Waitangi Tribunal held alongside the exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The Government recently announced a review of the Treaty of Waitangi Act 1975, which comes as the statute approaches its 50-year milestone on 10th October. The review is part of the coalition agreement between New Zealand First and National and will be led by an Independent Technical Advisory Group (ITAG), supported by Te Puni Kōkiri, to examine the whether the Waitangi Tribunal is “fit for purpose, not just for today, but for the generations to come.”
Joining us to discuss the topic of reform are Former Attorney-General and Treaty Minister Christopher Finlayson, and Matanuku Mahuika, who co-chaired the Waitangi Tribunal’s own Strategic Direction Review Group in 2024.
Tickets are $35 per session, or $25 for students and SuperGold Card holders, and include one drink and light kai. Doors open 5:30pm. The exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata will remain open to view until 8pm.
Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum
Wednesday 20 August | 6pm–8pm
Tickets $25–$35
This series has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.
Speakers:
Christopher Finlayson
The Hon. Christopher Finlayson served as an MP for 12 years, including as Attorney-General and Minister for Treaty of Waitangi Negotiations from 2008 to 2017. During his Ministerial career he also held a number of other portfolios. He is the co-author of He Kupu Taurangi: Treaty Settlements and the Future of Aotearoa New Zealand. He left politics in 2019 and now works for Bankside Chambers as a barrister.
Matanuku Mahuika
(Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Raukawa)
Matanuku Mahuika is one of Aotearoa’s leading Māori lawyers in private practice. He co-founded Kāhui Legal in 2003. Prior to establishing Kāhui Legal, Matanuku was a partner at Walters Williams & Co and in-house counsel at the Treaty of Waitangi Fisheries Commission.
This series has been developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

description:
Aroha Quartet and Friends, The popular Wellington-based Aroha String Quartet (violinists Haihong LIu and Konstanze Artmann. violist Zongxian Jin and cellist Robert Ibell) will be joined by four colleagues from the NZSO and Orchestra Wellington to present a rare performance of Schubert's famous Octet for Wind and Strings. This very substantial work of just under an hour's length has six movements, all of them brimming with warmth, charm and glorious melody. There is a wide variety of tonal colour as each of the instruments in turn shares the limelight, with delightful solo lines from violins, viola, cello, clarinet, bassoon, horn and double-bass. The clarinetist will be Nick Walshe, Justin Sun the bassoonist, joined by Alexander Hambleton (horn) and Oleksandr Gunchenko (double-bass).

Also on the programme will be a string quartet by Mozart (No 22 in B flat, K589) and a humorous light-hearted piece by Danish composer Carl Nielsen called "Serenata in Vano" in which a group of musicians attempt. unsuccessfully, to attract the attention of a young woman.

Door sales will be available for this concert, or tickets can be bought from Waikanae New World or Moby Dickens Books in Paraparaumu Beach. For booking enquiries go to www.waikanaemusic.org.nz or phone 021 147 4859.
