description:
Ōtari Raranga Hōngongoi 2025 - Intermediate, Ma te mōhio ka roa, ma te ora ka mōhio
Through learning there is life, through life there is learning

Nau mai haere mai, welcome to Ōtari Raranga Wānanga - Intermediate level

After completing about 6 beginner classes (close together) as well as practice at home you may be ready to move up to our intermediate classes. We will let you know.

We will be planning projects in advance to keep all on similar taonga.

PRojects may include new closes for your kete timata, kete waikawa, puritanga, pīkau and pōtae. We will teach you preparation, preservation and storage of harakeke - important especially over winter months.

Additionally, we will induct you to the Ōtari Pā Harakeke when ready.

With regular attendance you will deepen mātauranga gained from beginner classes and share you learnings with others. (Refer to below for a reminder).

What’s included in your intermediate ticket?
- Three hours+ weaving class with our tuakana weavers and raranga rangatira.
- Limited access to tools as you are expected to be have your own kete mahi (tool kit).
- You are expected to bring your own harakeke.
- We encourage you to harvest for yourself but if you are unable to harvest for class, we have ‘Please harvest for me’ options in addition to your ticket at least three days before class.
- Light refreshments are provided and we encourage you to bring kai to share

Led by our raranga Rangatira; Frank Topia (Ngā Puhi, Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Haua) with Linda Lee (Ngāti Huia, Ngāti Raukawa, Ngāti Kurī, Te Rarawa, Te Aupōuri), and Anna Lees (Te Āti Awa, Kāi Tahu). Supported by our kaiāwhina; Anita Murdoch (Ngāti Kahungunu and Waikato-Tainui), Sarah O’Sullivan (Ngāi Tahu), Te Kāhui Tapsell (Te Arawa, Tainui), and Frankie Stewart (Tangata Tiriti).

Important information
- It is important that everyone turns up on time for karakia.
- At our discretion tickets are fully refundable or transferable.
- If class numbers are too low, we may have to cancel (and will offer a refund or transfer) so please check your emails before class.
- We offer concession tickets for students, unwaged, seniors, and those with disabilities.
- It is important to us that our classes are accessible to all. If ticket costs are a barrier for you please visit our website to enquire about our reduced cost or free tickets.

Follow us on Facebook or Instagram: Otari Raranga Weavers

For more information about what to expect and what to bring visit our www.otariraranga.co.nz

TICKETING INFORMATION
Tuakana = Older sibling
Intermediate / Tuakana - General Admission: $25
Intermediate / Tuakana - Concession Admission: $20
Intermediate / Tuakana - Koha Admission: $15
Two Class Pass - Two back to back dates only: $45.00

ADD ON - Harvest for me: $20 + eventfinder fees (10 rau only) - 3 days notice required
ADD ON - Harvest for me: $40 + eventfinder fees (20 rau only) - 3 days notice required

Note: Eventfinda fees apply

We mihi to our funders and sponsors Wellington City Council, Wellington Gardens and the Ōtari-Wilton Bush Kaitiaki, Maverick Creative, Good Fortune Coffee and Wellington Apothecary.

With regular attendance you will:
- Learn tikanga (protocols) and karakia for hauhake (harvesting) and preparing harakeke
- Build your mātauranga (knowledge)
- Use kupu Māori appropriate to raranga practice
- Develop your pūkenga (practical skills)
- Create taonga (treasures) for your whānau
- Build hononga (connections) within our raranga rōpū (group)

Donations, Tax Credits and Corporate Gifting

- Shared Lines Trust is registered with Charities Service; Shared Lines Trust (CC61762)
- All donations over $5 made to The Trust are tax-deductible
- For corporate gifting or individuals requesting tax credits please email SharedLinesTrust@gmail.com
- Visit www.sharedlines.org.nz for more information

description:
A Change Is Coming walk tour (Wellington Heritage Festival), A Change Is Coming walk tour (Wellington Heritage Festival)
1pm, SUNDAY 19th OCTOBER 2025

2025 marks the 40th anniversary of the introduction in 1985, of the Homosexual Law Reform bill. The bill set out to decriminalise homosexual activity between consenting adults and make it illegal to discriminate against someone based on their sexual orientation.

But this wasn’t the first attempt at homosexual law reform. Join us on this special 90-minute free walk tour to celebrate the people and movements that fought for a brighter future for rainbow communities.

Our journey begins at the location of the first public meeting in New Zealand, advocating for homosexual law reform in 1967. This was two years before the Stonewall uprising in the U.S. which went on to ignite Gay Liberation around the world.

The tour ends at Parliament, where we honour the Members of Parliament who have championed equality over the last five decades.

Along the way, we’ll reflect on some of the difficult realities rainbow communities have faced, from the injustices of the legal system, to the stances of the medical profession, churches and the military. As the late activist Ralph Knowles recalls, “As far as medicine was concerned, it was sick. As far as the law was concerned, it was a crime. As far as the church was concerned, it was a sin.”

Though at times the stories are challenging, this walk tour is ultimately uplifting, as we pay tribute to our amazing rainbow kaumatua and allies who led the way.

COST: Free, but please register so we can manage the number of walkers: https://walktoursnz.wordpress.com/book/

DATE/TIME: 1pm, Sunday 19th October 2025

STARTS: meet at the rugby sculpture, Jack Ilott Green, corner of Harris Street & Jervois Quay (just by Civic Square)

ENDS: Parliament grounds

DURATION: 1 hour 30mins

ACCESSIBILITY: the tour is on flat public footpaths, with a light incline as we enter Parliament grounds. Tours are limited to approximately 20 walkers.

This tour is part of the amazing Wellington Heritage Festival - https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz

description:
Compliance made SME-asy: Employment basics with ATH Consulting, Are you confident in navigating the complexities of employment relationships in today’s ever-changing workplace? Join us for a comprehensive workshop designed for managers, employers, and business owners who want to deepen their understanding of employment fundamentals and people management best practices.
What You’ll Learn:
Foundations of Employment Relationships:
Explore the essential components that shape every employment relationship, including relevant legislation, terms and conditions, and the pivotal role of workplace policies and procedures.
Understanding Employment Types:
Distinguish between permanent, full-time, casual, and seasonal roles, and learn how each type impacts your obligations and management strategies.
Employment Legislation Essentials:
Get a practical overview of the 10 key employment laws that influence your workplace, ensuring you stay compliant and informed.
Good Faith and Agreements:
Discover the importance of acting in good faith and the differences between Individual Employment Agreements (IEA) and Collective Employment Agreements (CEA), including mandatory clauses and recommended “nice to have” terms.
Managing Change:
Learn best practices for handling variations to employment agreements and implementing effective workplace policies and procedures.
People Management Mastery:
Gain insights into the employee lifecycle, building a strong employment brand, and managing common workplace issues such as performance improvement plans (PiP), disciplinary processes, attendance, and health and wellbeing.
Leadership and Succession:
Identify the hallmarks of poor leadership and develop strategies for effective succession planning to future-proof your team.
Support Systems:
Know where to get help—learn when to trust your gut, when to rely on facts, and how to access the right support at the right time.
This workshop is your opportunity to build confidence, reduce risk, and enhance your leadership toolkit. Whether you’re new to managing people or looking to refresh your knowledge, you’ll leave with practical insights and actionable strategies for every stage of the employment relationship.
Don’t miss this chance to strengthen your employment management skills and connect with peers facing similar challenges. Register now and take the next step toward becoming a more effective, knowledgeable, and resilient leader.
When: Wednesday 10 September 9.00 am - 11.00 am
Where: Carterton Community Courthouse (next to Events Centre) Holloway Street, Carterton
Cost: Members $65 + GST, Non-Members $120 +GST
This workshop needs a minimum of 15 attendees to go ahead.

All tickets to this show have sold. Second show announcement soon...

This will be Darren's first performance in the Wellington region in almost half a decade! Strictly limited tickets so book early to avoid disappointment.

Enjoy an amazing night with legendary blues artist Darren Watson. Darren is a seasoned singer-songwriter and blues musician with over three decades of experience in the music industry. Based in Aotearoa/New Zealand, Darren has built a reputation for his authentic blues sound, combining traditional influences with contemporary themes. His music is characterised by thoughtful lyrics, skilled guitar work, and a voice that carries both grit and soul.

With Darren for this intimate Shed appearance will be stellar double bassist Steve Moodie, and once wunderkind but still wunderful guitarist Chris Armour.

Darren first gained recognition in the 1980s as the leader and frontman of the New Zealand band Chicago Smoke Shop. Since then, he has pursued a successful solo career, releasing a series of well-received albums. His 2020 album, Getting Sober for the End of the World, was widely praised for its sharp social commentary and musical craftsmanship, earning airplay and accolades both locally and internationally. It saw Darren nominated as a finalist for the 2021 Aotearoa Music Award for Best Folk Artist.

Watson's new album 'Darren Watson sings John Hiatt' is due for release in late 2025.

description:
Book Reading: Noho Tahi 和平共處 by Noho Tahi Collective, We're thrilled to host this event to celebrate Noho Tahi | 和平共處 by Noho Tahi Collective, with 5ever Books.
Noho Tahi | 和平共處 is the inaugural residency project for The Dan and Una Chan & Laywood and Joyce Chan Residency at Wai-te-ata Press. The Residency’s focus is on “projects that enhance understandings of and engagement with Chinese Aotearoa, whether historical, social or cultural.
Speakers on the night are: Etienne Wain 黃義天 , Juhyeon 주현, brenda wang, Brecon Dobbie 布雷肯.
This multimedia collection reflects on noho tahi | 和平共處, peaceful co-existence between cultures — an emerging invitation for Hainamana/NZ Chinese communities to reorient ourselves towards Tangata Whenua in ways that uphold Tikanga Māori, Te Tiriti o Waitangi, and the diversities and complexities within Hainamanatanga (Chinese ways of being in Aotearoa).
Nau mai, haere mai! 入嚟坐!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Book Launch: Rangatiratanga & Gentlemanship: A Conversation in 1825 by Grant Hodgson, Join us in the shop to celebrate the launch of Rangatiratanga & Gentlemanship: A conversation in 1825 by Grant Hodgson published by Writes Hill Press.
“From the great sedimentary layers of historical documents on New Zealand’s colonisation, Hodgson has extracted a nugget that reveals so much about the nature of interactions between Māori and Pākehā in the earliest stages of settlement. With great insight, this short work illuminates the significance of this period of contact.” ~ Professor Paul Moon ONZM, historian
This book examines a rare piece of evidence illustrating the initial conditions of the relation­ship between Māori and missionaries at Kerikeri in 1825.
All welcome!
label: Community & Culture

description:
CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA, CUBAN☆FUSION's Annualish PINK Cuba St Salsa Party Breast Cancer Fundraiser's 9th Anniversary - KOHA
On the 9th of October it will sadly be 9 years since our little sister Wilhelmina died of a particularly aggressive form of breast cancer just 3 weeks short of her 50th birthday and a week before her eldest of 4 girls' 16th birthday, which we bought forward a week so she could be there to celebrate it. She took her last breath at 6.06pm the next day while our father (RIP) and I held her hands and my brother played his guitar at her feet.. with Charles Humphreys at her head and our Mum and her girls looking on, and while Rafael and Sjaak held the fort and kicked off Sunday Salsa at The Cross.. in my absence.

***

PLEASE JOIN US DRESSED IN AS MUCH PINK AS POSSIBLE IN CUBA MALL ON FRIDAY 1 NOVEMBER @ 6PM - THE DAY BEFORE OUR SISTER'S ("MINA'") WOULD HAVE BEEN 58TH BIRTHDAY - TO CELEBRATE LIFE IN PINK 🩷 LA VITA IN ROSA 🩷 LEVEN IN ROZE 🩷 LA VIDA EN ROSA 🩷 LA VIE EN ROSE 🩷 ORA I ROTO I TE MAWHERO 🩷 AND TO RAISE AS MUCH AS WE CAN FOR BCFNZ.

***

CUBAN☆FUSION - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists' famous Cuba Street Salsa Party is going PINK this November for a very good cause - The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ.

What better place to dance Salsa than in the street, Cuba Street to be exact.

Don't worry if you don't know how to dance, we'll teach you!

Dress Code: PINK!

Help us raise awareness and funds for a very good cause and have a good time at the same time.. the Cuban way.. dancing the night away under the stars!

Suggested Koha/Donation: $5

Aiming to fund-raise $1,000 this year.. that's only 200 people @ $5 dancing Salsa in Cuba Street all PINKed up. We can do it!

EFTPOS available - 1.1% surcharge applies.

Alternatively, (or if you can't make it to the event, but would like to contribute) you can also donate on-line to our dedicated Pink Party account:

02-0343-0003801-007

ALL donations will go directly to The Breast Cancer Foundation NZ to help them in their mission to educate and find better cures.

Please give generously.

LOCATION: You will find us in "La Plaza" - the open space between the Bucket Fountain and the Left Bank Lane in Cuba Mall.

NB: This event is weather dependent. Decision to relocate or postpone will be made by 4pm at the latest on the day.

RAIN DATE: TBC

***

This event annualish (thanks to COVID) is dedicated to the memory of CUBAN☆FUSION's Co-Founder Rosina van der Aa's little sister Wilhelmina van der Aa, who died three weeks short of her 50th birthday on 9 October 2016 of very aggressive secondary breast cancer leaving behind four gorgeous girls and one loving husband.

#because_we_need_a_cure_not_a_miracle
#dontwalkby
#takeaction
#donate
#dancesalsa
#wearpink
#keepcalmdancecuban

Today 8 women will be diagnosed with Breast Cancer

Yet 30% of eligible women are not enrolled for free screening

This year 600+ will most likely die from Breast Cancer

And 60% of women do not know the signs beyond a lump

Knowledge is power… and knowledge helps beat breast cancer. Get knowledgeable here: https://www.breastcancerfoundation.org.nz/breast-awareness

Remember if you are 45-69 and not enrolled for free mammograms you can enrol by calling BreastScreen Aotearoa on 0800 270 200.

To find out more about CUBAN☆FUSION, its dance classes and upcoming dance and music event please visit our website.

CUBAN☆FUSION © 2005 - Wellington's Cuban Salsa Specialists | www.cubanfusion.co.nz | | 021-621-245

description:
CHAPPELL vs CHARLI: A Drag Fundraiser Smackdown, Friday 27 September | 9.30pm @ Ivy Bar, Pōneke
Tickets: $20 (excluding ticket fees) | Generosity options available!
All proceeds to Wellington Pride Festival!

Kia ora! brats and popstars! Get your heads out the passenger seat and get ready, cause your about to be bumpin’ that with some of wellington drags finest!
Royalty is stepping into the ring (well, the stage) for CHAPPELL vs CHARLI : a high-camp, high-stakes, drag smackdown showdown, where our fabulous local drag artists channel the icons of Charli XCX and Chappell Roan to battle it out for title of 'Queen of the Chartsverse'… all in the name of charity xx

Three lip sync rounds. Four drag titans. One glitter-drenched champion.
Each round sees performers pull a mystery song each from their assigned diva’s discography and fight for the crown based on lip sync accuracy and undeniable star quality. Think charity boxing... but queerer. Like, much queerer. Only you! The audience! And our incredible judge Rachel Winter Hase, can determine our number #1 pop icon!

Featuring:
- Homer Neurotic (multi-award-winning drag king)
- Slay West (the biggest mouth in the biz)
- Petra Fyde (now your petrified)
- Ms. Leading (Your big bros lil secret)
(and Olivia Dreams on door)

Hosted by the ever-glamorous Selina Simone, and judged by local performance legend Rachel Winter Hase, who will deliver her pop verdicts with love and lashes *whipcrack.mp3

A high-speed crash of glitter, vocals, and vengeance! Expect drag, drama, and come ready to holler, hoot, bump and help decide who is our ultimate XCX BRAT or CHAPPELL POPSTAR!

Tickets: Just $20 + fees, with donation options for those feeling generous – every cent raised goes to support Wellington Pride Festival, helping make 2025 the queerest yet!

Accessibility: Ivy Bar is located downstairs but alternative access is possible with prior planning. Please email theselinasimone@gmail.com so we can accommodate you. If you wish to attend and donate, but cost is an issue for you, please reach to me as well xx
label: Community & Culture

description:
It's in the Ballot - Tararua District Council – South Ward -In-studio, Contestants of 'It's in the Bag' become political candidates in 'It's in the Ballot' Meet the Candidates.
Candidates choose a numbered box which has a question that has been submitted online by voters before the show.
It’s in the Ballot” is a community-led awareness and participation initiative. We aim to increase voter interest in the general and council elections nationally.
By using broadcasting and web-based technologies to deliver in-studio; online on Facebook, YouTube and Twitch; and edited as YouTube videos we aim to enable voters to make informed voting decisions.
This means you can send the weblink of the YouTube Video of your electorate show to your friends and whanau to encourage them to watch the show before they cast their votes.
Voting papers are sent to voters on Tuesday 9th September 2025 and must be delivered into a voting dropbox by 12pm Saturday 11th October 2025
label: Government & Politics

description:
Cocktail Night 2025, VicCom Presents... Cocktail Night 2025 🥂
While we sadly won’t be hosting the Commerce Ball this year, we’re not leaving you without a reason to dress up! VicCom is excited to invite you to an elegant evening at The Library Bar on Courtenay Place, for a night of cocktails, food, music, and a great time.
This is your chance to gather with friends, enjoy a lively atmosphere, and make memories in one of Wellington’s most iconic cocktail lounges. Whether you were planning to attend the Ball or are simply looking for a fun night out, Cocktail Night is the perfect excuse to get dressed up and raise a glass with us. 🥂
🌟 Your Ticket Includes: 🌟
Entry to The Library’s private function space 🍷
A complimentary drink on arrival 🍹
Delicious food served throughout the night 🍴
🎟️ Tickets
$20 — VicCom Member (please enter your student ID as a Discount Code)
$30 — Non-VicCom Member
📅 Event Details
Date: Friday 19th September, 2025
Time: 7:00pm until late
Venue: Lovebite, The Library Bar
Address: 2 Forresters Lane, Te Aro, Wellington
❓ FAQs
Q: Do I need to dress up?
A: Not necessarily, but we'd love it if you did! We're not going to let that dress rental go to waste...
Q: I already bought a Commerce Ball ticket. What now?
A: You’ll receive a full refund for your Ball ticket and a complimentary Cocktail Night ticket automatically. You will have received an email with instructions on how to secure your free ticket.
Q: Do I need to be 18 to attend?
A: Yes. This is an R18 event, so you must be born on or before 19/09/2007.

description:
Cèilidh Dance Fundraiser for WMC, Get your dancing shoes on and bring the kids! The Wellington Music Centre invites you to join a vibrant and lively evening of traditional Scottish and Irish social dancing, featuring the sensational VicFolk band! This beginner-friendly, all-ages partner dancing event is designed to bring families and the community together for a night of fun, music, and connection, all while supporting the Wellington Music Centre.

Details

12th September 2025
6 - 9pm
St Patrick's Hall, 17 Rongotai Road, Kilbirnie
Ages 0-99
Tickets:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/.../wmc-ceili-dance
(door sales will be available)
Activities
Traditional Partner Dancing: Learn and enjoy traditional Scottish and Irish dances, led by the VicFolk caller*, making it perfect for beginners and families.
Live Music: Dance the night away to the energetic and foot-stomping tunes provided by the sensational VicFolk band.
Raffle: Grab a ticket to our raffle for a chance to win fantastic prizes!
Silent Auction: Bid on unique items and experiences donated by local businesses in our silent auction, including tickets to Roxy cinema, and a family pass to Wēta Workshop, with all proceeds supporting the Wellington Music Centre.
Food and Drinks: Food and beverages are available for purchase throughout the evening. This is an alcohol-free event.
*the caller leads the band and calls out instructions for the dancers, usually with a good sense of humour! They make sure everyone is having a great time, especially those who have never attended a cèilidh dance before.

Supporting Wellington Music Centre:
A cèilidh is about more than dancing, it’s a place to enjoy time with your family and connect as a community. At Wellington Music Centre, we are passionate about bringing joyful and affordable musical experiences to kids and families in South and East Wellington. Proceeds from the event will directly benefit the Wellington Music Centre, helping to fund our great programmes, including the Peninsula Family Choir, the Miramar Kids Choir, the Wellington Music Centre Orchestra, our foundational music courses: Music Explorers and the Ukulele Ensemble, and our free twice-a-year community events.
You can read more about the Wellington Music Centre and our fantastic programmes on our website:
https://www.wellingtonmusiccentre.org.nz/
label: Community & Culture

description:
Community Evening Trimester 2 2025, About Ignite:
Ignite Consultants is a student-run charitable organisation that provides free and creative advice to charities and social organisations across Aotearoa. All of our consultants are passionate and talented student-volunteers who are driven by their desire to foster social change. Our vision is to help organisations to maximise their impact through harnessing the fresh perspectives of university students. 
We run two project cycles per year which coincide with the university semesters, each lasting for a duration of 9 weeks. Each team consists of a local charity, 5-6 students, a project manager (a person who has been through the Ignite Consultants experience before) and a professional mentor who has experience in consulting and/or the industry the organisation works in. 
About the Event:
Ignite's Community Evening is a special occasion where our consultants share what they have learnt, created and experienced over the past nine weeks. This event is an opportunity to learn about the remarkable charities we have collaborated with this semester, to enjoy delicious food and to extend our heartfelt thanks to all our supporters. 
This semester, attendees will get to hear presentations from the teams who have worked with WELLfed, Take10, Orange Sky, PACE and The Charitable Recycling Trust. 
To join us virtually, please click on the link below:
label: Community & Culture

description:
DRAG BINGO with Felicity Frockaccino! @DLS, Darling, This is not your grandma's Bingo! the original bingo b*tch is back! FELICITY 'THE FROCK' FROCKACCINO
Brace yourself for an evening dripping with glamour, sparkle, and a whole lot of cheek as you soak in the skyline of Wellington's most unique rooftop hideaway
DIRTY LITTLE SECRET!
Slip into something fabulous, grab your favorite drink, and get ready for an extravagant night of DRAG BINGO! We've got cocktails that'll make you blush, and more laughs than you can shake a feather boa at!
Expect live drag performances to make your heart race, dad jokes that'll have you in stitches, and beats from our fabulous local DJs that'll keep you moving all night long! Book your table for 7.00pm, balls dropping 7.30 at the latest!
Event Highlights:
Hold onto your wigs, honey, because it's FREE to enter! And we have well over $200 worth of PRIZES to be won! including our grand prize... $100.00 BAR VOUCHER! odds not in your favour? we have SPOT PRIZES up for grabs!
Oh, why not order some our epic drink and kai specials!
Get your gang together, you've got to book a table to secure your spot! let's turn this night into a campy, sexy extravaganza!
Reserve your table for 7:00 pm, bookings are hot, so snatch yours now through the link below (or the ticket link on this page) https://dirtylittlesecret.co.nz/events/drag-bingo/ Limited Walk-In's on the night
xx
Immerse yourself in enchanting breathtaking views that will elevate your experience. From the glittering city lights to the stars above, DIRTY LITTLE SECRET is Wellington's most unique rooftop bar, offering a setting as sensational as the entertainment!
But wait, the fun doesn't stop there! Our sensational DJ will be spinning tunes from around 9/9:30 pm 'til late. Let's keep the dance floor sizzling and the party vibes alive!
For our guests with specific accessibility needs, we have elevator access to ensure everyone can join in on the fun. However, as some tables are on raised bits of flooring, we encourage those with accessibility requirements to reach out to us directly. Your comfort is our priority, and we're here to make sure your night is as fabulous as can be!
LGBTQIA+ Friendly: Our staff and security at Dirty Little Secret are not just friendly; they're fabulous! Trained to meet the needs of all our diverse patrons, ensuring a safe, and welcoming space for everyone xx
TRIGGER WARNINGS: This is an R18 event! Expect strong language, good vibes, and thotty danger and legs so smooth they'll sweep you off your feet!—100% guaranteed! xx

description:
Taste Kāpiti, Taste Kāpiti
Celebrate your year with Taste!
A boutique beverage mini fest created to celebrate the unique flavours and producers of Aotearoa’s regions.

With successful events in Whanganui, Kāpiti, and now Tauranga, each Taste Festival is thoughtfully curated to bring together local producers, food trucks and live music in a beautiful outdoor setting.
Founded and run by event professionals with a passion for local culture and connection, Taste K`apiti is a high-quality food and drink experience in a vibrant and relaxed setting that doubles as a perfect end-of-year celebration for friends & families, teams & businesses.
Want to elevate your Taste experience? Check out our VIP/Corporate tickets/tables.
Includes:
A festive lunch, two signature cocktails, and access to our exclusive VIP area – complete with premium seating, shade, and great vibes.
Join us on the beautiful waterfront to eat well, drink local, and celebrate the best of the season!

description:
Celebrating 132 years of women’s suffrage — special lunchtime tour and kōrero, Join our kaimahi for a special lunchtime tour and kōrero, highlighting the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition | Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine, which paved the way for women’s suffrage in Aotearoa.
Tour and kōrero
Mark your calendars for 19 September, the anniversary of the 1893 Electoral Act that granted New Zealand women the right to vote in parliamentary elections.
To celebrate Suffrage Day, join a 45-minute kōrero and tour of the 1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
Tours are open to visitors of all ages (age 6+). Booking is not required.
Please meet at our waka reception desk on the ground floor before the start of the tour.
The ongoing struggle for equal rights
Come along to the National Library to learn about the journey New Zealand women took to gain the right to vote and about the ongoing struggle for equal rights.
View the 1893 petition that led to the creation of the Electoral Act 1893, which was signed into law on 19 September 1893.
Hear stories about wāhine toa like Meri Te Tai Mangakāhia (Te Rarawa) and suffragists Kate Sheppard, Ada Wells and maybe an ancestor of your own.

description:
FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST, FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST
FRISKY is celebrating HALLOWEEN a week early this October 18th! Join us for FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST - a magical dance party deep in the woods.

Enter the FRISKY FORBIDDEN FOREST, where the magical world comes alive after dark. This dance party invites all creatures to enter the forbidden forest and lose themselves in a night of spellbinding beats and untamed revelry.

THEME & DRESS CODE: “HALLOWEEN” ✨ Magical, Mysterious, and a Little Bit Mischievous ✨
Costumes are mandatory.

DJS: DJ Jimmy Fade (Wellington), DJ Harry K (Brisbane), DJ James Johnson (Auckland)

COAT CHECK: $5 (Please bring your own bag for loose items)

FRISKY Parties are queer, genderqueer, trans & non-binary friendly parties where all are welcome to join in the fun.

Follow us on social media for updates: @djjimmyfade, @wellington_partyboys and @friskyeventsnz

description:
Fareham Journey Free Cohousing Information & Tour, Fareham Journey is building a sustainable cohousing community in Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston and they are looking for people who share their kaupapa to create this with us. The Fareham property has extensive grounds which includes a historic home, and established organic gardens, an orchard, and fields. It even has an arts community on site.

We run these free cohousing information and tour events on the third Sunday of every month, from noon until 2pm at Fareham, 80 Underhill Road, Pae Tū Mōkai, Featherston in the South Wairarapa.

Learn about the Fareham Journey and our vision to create a sustainable and supportive community and how you can get involved. We invite you to bring a plate of vegetarian food to join us for a shared meal in the historic homestead, Fareham House, followed by the tour.

Ensure you RSVP to attend at https://farehamjourney.nz/rsvp/

description:
Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time, Echoes of Home: A Musical Journey Across Time
An emotional musical journey that brings us back to childhood memories and the timeless charm of traditional Vietnamese melodies

About this Event

Event Information
Some days remind us who we are and where we come from — when an entire nation moves as one to honour Independence.
To celebrate the 80th Anniversary of Vietnam’s National Day (2 September), Viet Hub NZ proudly presents
“Echoes of Home – A Musical Across Time”

This free concert is a heartfelt journey through the sounds of Vietnamese history — from nostalgic childhood songs to powerful wartime ballads and modern melodies of pride and hope. All performances will include English subtitles, making it easy for everyone to follow along and connect with the stories.
Whether you’re Vietnamese or simply curious about a different culture, this is a wonderful opportunity to experience the warmth, resilience, and beauty of Vietnam through music and storytelling.



🎁 Raffle with Over $300 in Prizes
Don’t miss our special raffle on the day. Tickets will be available at the venue for $5 and $10. Payment can be made in cash or by bank transfer.

💛 Support Viet Hub NZ
This event is free to attend, but if you believe in what we do and want to help us continue running community workshops, cultural events, and youth-led initiatives — please consider making a donation.
👉 Donate here: https://givealittle.co.nz/cause/viet-hub-nz-rooted-in-culture-powered-by-community
Your koha helps keep our work going, rooted in culture, powered by community.

description:
Fluid Art Workshop, Fluid Art Workshop
Spend an evening unwinding with paint, good food, and good company. This beginner-friendly class is designed for everyone—you don’t need to be an artist to enjoy it. All the materials will be ready for you, and you’ll get to explore blacklight-reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints, experimenting with marble and swirl effects to create something completely your own.
Since the paint takes a few days to fully dry, your artwork will stay safely with us—you’ll be able to come back on Sunday to pick it up.
It can get a bit messy, so come in clothes you don’t mind getting paint on, and tie your hair back if it’s long.
After the painting, relax over a wholesome plant-based dinner and dessert, the perfect way to finish a creative and relaxed night.
Meet your host, Alannah
Alannah has been fascinated by blacklight art since she was 15 and has been exploring different mediums to find what really stands out for 20 years. She takes inspiration from all the wonderful artists she encounters in the real world and online. She noticed that this particular type of fluid art hadn't really been done the way she does it, so she has developed her own unique style utilising blacklight reactive and glow-in-the-dark paints. Let her colour your world and explore the possibilities of fluid art together.
................................................................................................
Booking for Thursday is recommended!
For more details and to book please go here--
https://bit.ly/eventTickets
...............................................................................................
Make Thursdays your night to connect and take a break from your week. Events range from creative workshops, wellness courses to entertaining experiences. All within a down-to-earth and welcoming space. Each event wraps up with a plant-based dinner and dessert.
...............................................................................................
Bhakti Lounge
1/175 Vivian Street
Wellington

description:
Family Watercolour Art Class - Island Bay, In this class all the family can share 2 hours of creative fun together and grown ups can join in for youth price of $25. All materials supplied including quality watercolour paper, just arrive empty handed and two hours they will have a completed painting. No previous art experience is required as these workshops are suitable for both beginners and artists who’d like to fine tune their skills and style a little further. Don’t worry about drawing as this will be done so we can focus on the joys of watercolour painting. A step-by step teaching style is used and this all happens in a wonderful, relaxed and enjoyable classroom overlooking the harbour.

Check out other classes, each has a different subject to choose from, Also available are Saturday family art classes as well as Wine & Watercolour evenings on Friday and Saturday evenings.

description:
Father's Day Quiz, Put your general knowledge to the test while supporting a great cause at the Father's Day Quiz!
Join us for a belated celebration of the fathers and father figures in our lives. We welcome everyone to join us, including students and mothers, so make sure to get everyone a ticket.
Date: Monday 8 September
Time: 6:30pm-9pm
Cost: $25 per person, which includes a pizza dinner and a drink
Please bring gold coins for some exciting games to be played throughout the evening.
This event is part of the 2025 Middle School Challenge fundraiser for Blind Low Vision NZ. Our Middle School Leaders have the unique opportunity to sponsor the development and training of a Guide Dog named Cooper, which costs about $25,000. Your generous donations are greatly appreciated and make a significant difference. Once Cooper is fully trained, he will be placed with a visually impaired person for the rest of his working life. We believe that as the Scots Community bands together, your support can change a life.
To learn more or to make a donation, visit our Givealittle page.

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Gallows Tour, Crime, Justice, and the Final Walk.
Delve into the complex history of capital punishment in Wellington with this thought-provoking tour through Karori Cemetery. Gallows shines a light on the people behind the process. Discover their roles in shaping justice, the cases that defined their careers, and the human stories behind a system of ultimate consequence.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day 1 hour before the tour starts by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 2 hours long.
This tour contains a number of adult themes and some graphic descriptions so is not suitable for everyone.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions.
While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
If you have purchased tickets for other people can you please pass our tour information on to them as well.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery - 2025 Wellington Heritage Festival: Tales from the Vaults Tour, Tales from the Vaults.
Find out who is in and who is out of some of Karori cemetery’s most substantial dwellings. Note: tours do not enter vaults or try them out for size. 
The tour duration is 1 hour 45mins.
This tour is suitable for people with moderate fitness. The route mostly follows paved surfaces but there are some areas of unevenness. Surefootedness is required. This tour involves approximately 2km of walking, with some slow paced but uphill stints

Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Note:
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you on the day by 9am by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
This tour is approximately 1 hour and 45 minutes long
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
Some of our walks require a moderate degree of fitness and are not suited for those with limited mobility. Please read the tour descriptions carefully to check that they will be suitable for you.
There is only one toilet which is located by the cemetery office at the main entrance.
Please meet us at the shelter (shown as the Historic Chapel on the map at the main entrance)
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
A Good Time to Sing!, There is so much going on in the world right now, and that can be overwhelming! Now is a good time to sing. A good time to get together and feel the power of community and connection through singing.

Sing for renewal and hope. Sing for harmony, joy, and inspiration. Sing for healing. Sing to regain your strength and empower others.

Spend the day at the serene sanctuary that is the Home of Compassion in Island Bay and restore yourself.

We will breathe together, listen, create beautiful sounds, let go of our worries, and lift each other to a sense of fulfillment and joy.

And for the perfect finishing touch, a delicious lunch and morning tea are all included. All you need to do is come along!

Jonathan Berkahn and Lala Simpson have been working together, leading workshops and performing for many years. They are both highly skilled song leaders who lead from the heart and joyfully share their gifts. You will be in safe hands.

description:
Futuna Lecture Series 2025: Francis Kéré, The Futuna Lecture Series commenced in 2011 and has been one of the main annual events on the NZ Architectural calendar for the last 14 years. It is the Futuna Chapel Trust’s major fundraiser each year and attracts a large audience of architects, architectural designers, technicians, architecture and design students and interested members of the public. The Trust exists solely on koha/donations as well as financial support from selected sponsors and donors.
Our sponsors, Dulux NZ, APL, Plytech, Warren Trust and the Auckland, Christchurch and Wellington NZIA branches have continued their support for the Futuna Lecture Series 2025.
This year the Trust welcomes three new sponsors being Roofing Industries Limited, AGP and Big River Panels. The additional support of these new sponsors is very much appreciated and ensures that the Futuna Chapel Trust can continue to attract speakers to NZ of a similar calibre to that of the 2025 Futuna Lecture, Francis Kéré.
The Trust takes this opportunity to thank Metalcraft Roofing for their support of the Futuna Lecture Series from 2012 - 2024.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work and well as that of the Kéré Foundation.
The Trust will donate 20% of the ticket income to the Kéré Foundation to support the work of Francis Kéré in Gando, Burkina Faso.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. Please register using the ticket types of $10, $15, $25 or $30 GST inclusive. Booking fees are in addition to the ticket prices.
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when purchasing Architect tickets
label: Community & Culture

description:
Friends of Karori Cemetery: National Monuments (Dec 2025), The two main stops on the tour are the Cemeteries’ two national Monuments – the Tangiwai disaster and Prime Minister Peter Fraser.  We will review what happened at Tangiwai and especially the bravery of the trains crew and in addition, what the court of inquiry found about the safety of the bridge. 
Peter Fraser is generally regarded as one of NZ’s best Prime Ministers of the 20th century, and we explore his initiatives in public health and education and also his leadership during WW2.
These are just two of the several stops we will make.
Each tour is $10 per person (plus non-refundable booking fee). Children under 12 are free.
Our tour has a maximum capacity of about 15 persons. If there are insufficient tickets remaining for your party, please email us at info@friendsofkaroricemetery.co.nz to check if we can accommodate you.
Please note:
This tour requires reasonable physical fitness and sadly is not suited for those with limited mobility. 
If we have to cancel a tour due to inclement weather or sickness, we will notify you 1 hour before the tour start time by email and on our Facebook page. The booking fee is non-refundable.
Please dress appropriately for the conditions. While we do our best to guide you on a safe walking route, during the winter months the ground can become slippery in places.
We look forward to welcoming you to Karori Cemetery.

description:
Victorian Photography Workshop with Brian Scadden, Victorian Photography Workshop with Brian Scadden
DATE: Sunday Sept 28
TIME: 9:30am-1:30pm
LOCATION: Cobblestones Museum, Greytown
AGES: Over 18
COST: $135 per person. Max 5 people.
Come and have a go at wet-plate collodion photography, using authentic materials to produce your own heirloom image as were made 170 years ago. This almost lost art produces one-of-a-kind images on tin or glass plates, which you create and have an image you’ve crafted to take away.

Brian Scadden will be your instructor for this workshop. Brain has been passionate about photography for over 40 years, beginning his career at the National Film Unit in the 1970s before joining Park Road Post Production as Head of Laboratory, Head of Picture, and Restoration Manager. His work in film sparked an interest in early photographic techniques, prompting him to master wet-plate collodion photography. In 2006, he was invited to assist leading wet-plate experts in the USA and has since taught many New Zealanders this challenging process. Jane, who attended Brian’s workshop in 2014, later married him in 2019 and completed a photographic project in Carterton in 2016.
Although Brian retired in 2015, he returned for short-term assignments at Park Road Post and part-time work at Archive NZ, supporting film archiving until mid-2023. Both Brian and Jane continue to shoot with 35mm and 120mm film using vintage cameras from their collection.

NOTE: Link for booking tickets coming soon.

Email:
www.greytownarttown.com

description:
Gender Attitudes Survey Launch 2025, Kia ora koutou,
The National Council of Women of New Zealand / Te Kaunihera Wāhine o Aotearoa (NCWNZ) warmly invites you to the launch of our Gender Attitudes Survey, sharing the latest perceptions of gender equality in Aotearoa.
Join us on Wednesday, 17 September at the Tiakiwai Conference Centre at the National Library where we will present the key findings from our 5th biannual survey. The Gender Attitudes Survey measures New Zealanders’ views on gender roles in the home, education, workplaces, and in the wider community. We will explore how attitudes have changed since our first baseline survey in 2017, and what these results mean for advancing gender equality in Aotearoa New Zealand.
We will be hosting an amazing group of speakers on the day to talk about the Survey results and what that means for gender equality in New Zealand. More information will be available on this page when speakers are confirmed. Watch the space!
Speakers
Host, Suzanne Manning, President, NCWNZ
Suzanne Manning is the current President of NCWNZ, having been involved for 20 years as a member. She has a background in education and social research, and is passionate about progress towards gender equality.
Keynote speaker: Professor Gail Pacheco
Professor Gail Pacheco is the Equal Employment Opportunities (EEO) Commissioner at the Human Rights Commission. A leading economist, she has previously been the Director of the NZ Policy Research Institute at AUT and a Commissioner at the NZ Productivity Commission. She has an extensive track record of social policy-focused research, often leading large-scale collaborations between academia, community organisations, and the public sector.
Gail has been the recipient of numerous awards. These include: the 2018 NZIER Economics Award for outstanding contributions to the advancement of economics and its applications in NZ; the AUT Medal in 2019 in recognition of her use of integrated data to inform social policy and wellbeing; and most recently, in 2025, she was awarded Life Membership of the New Zealand Association of Economists, an honour reserved for individuals who have made significant contributions to both the association and the economics profession in NZ.
Emanuel Kalafatelis, Research New Zealand
Emanuel has been involved in the social and marketing research industry in Aotearoa New Zealand for over 40 years. For most of those years, he has managed a wholly independent research company, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, based in Wellington and mainly servicing clients in the public sector. In addition to the Gender Attitudes Survey, Emanuel has led and been involved in several ‘landmark’ research projects, including projects aimed at measuring New Zealanders’ attitudes to subject topics such as changing the New Zealand flag, New Zealand becoming a republic, the sale of public assets, genetic modification and the impact of COVID-19. Emanuel is a Fellow and current member of the Research Association of New Zealand Inc.
Dellwyn Stewart, CE YWCA Auckland, Board member NCWNZ
Dellwyn Stuart is a leader with a track record of developing and executing transformational strategy, successfully influencing decision makers and stakeholders, and finding solutions in complex, ambiguous environments. Currently as CEO of YWCA, she is passionate about contributing to a future for Aotearoa that is more equitable for all, and finds joy and optimism in her work with young women. Her career spans the commercial and not for profit sectors with a depth of knowledge and experience in philanthropy, fundraising, stakeholder engagement and gender issues.
Youth speaker (name and bio to come)
In-person and virtual attendance
If you’re joining us in person, there will be light refreshments after the launch when you can enjoy conversation with other attendees. Online tickets are also available. Please note that this event will be live streamed from 6pm and recorded for sharing after the launch.
Acknowledgments
The Gender Attitudes Survey and launch are generously supported by the Manatu Wahine Ministry for Women, Rangahau Aotearoa Research New Zealand, YWCA Auckland.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Are You Smarter Than A Drag Queen? - A Drag Trivia Night ( WELLINGTON ), Join Rosa Violeta and Yuri Guaii, star of RuPaul’s Drag Race Down Under and The Boulet Brothers’ Dragula, as we finally answer the age-old question: Are You Smarter Than a Drag Queen?

This is a trivia night unlike any other.. packed with fabulous prizes, outrageous drag shows, chaotic banter, and questions that’ll have you questioning everything.
Grab your smartest (or stupidest) friends and head to Saint Diablo in Wellington on October 24rd for a night of camp, cocktails, and competition. Expect stunning looks, unhinged lip-syncs, and maybe even a heated debate over who really invented the Pavlova.
Think you’ve got what it takes to win? There’ll be prizes, bragging rights, and chaotic glory up for grabs and not just for the trivia champs. Whether you nail the answers or charm your way through the madness, you might just walk away with something fabulous… or hilariously useless.
Tickets are $35 per person excl ticketing fees - 6:30PM to 9:00PM.
Seats are limited, so snatch yours now and don’t miss the most glamorous quiz night of the season!
For enquiries please contact Rosa Violeta at therosavioleta@gmail.com

description:
Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival), Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever (Wellington Heritage Festival)
STARTS: 1pm, SUNDAY 2 NOV

In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender Member of Parliament in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally on the grounds of Parliament.

Never a bystander, Georgina faced down the bigots, telling them straight, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” This was just one of many significant moments that shaped the life of the extraordinary Georgina Beyer.

Born in Wellington, Georgina went on to have an unprecedented local, national and international impact through her commitment to equality and her desire to give everyone the opportunity to reach their full potential in society.

Join us for this special 90-minute walking tour as we pay tribute to the late Georgina (1957–2023) by visiting locations around central Wellington that shaped her journey. Along the way, we’ll honour some of her heroes and listen to first-hand archival audio clips that showcase her humour and resilience.

Georgina’s story is defiantly optimistic – confronting hardship and using her lived experience to change the world for the better.

description:
Kareoke & Disco Fundraiser, Ultimate Kareoke Disco Fundraiser Night! Let’s send me to Australia in style!
Malo families & friends, as you all know I got picked for the Wellington Samoa cricket tour to Australia — but I need your help to cover my ticket, kit, and subs. This is my FINAL DANCE to fund this dream, and I’m counting on you to bring the vibes, the laughs, and the support!
Date, place & vibes:
Saturday 6th Sep
Cutlers Entertainment, The Hutt
6:00 PM – Midnight
Let’s light up the floor and keep the good energy rolling all night long!
What’s happening:
Kareoke & Disco Party Night — you bring the voice, we bring the glory!
Cash prizes: Winner takes home $500
, 2nd, 3rd and 4th places take home a NSW or Maroon hoodie (your pick)

Sing solo or in a crew — 10 lucky peeps get to perform the beat between 9:30pm to 11pm
Entry to perform: only $50 per seat (book fast — only 10 spots!)
Tickets to watch and dance: Online $20 | Door $25
How to join the fun:
Want to sing? Message me NOW to grab your seat!

Kareoke entry deadline: 30th Aug — don’t miss out!
Song submission for the night: 1st Sep — we’ll be ready to roll!
Tickets to dance & watch: inbox me — I’ll send your number once you book and pay

Payment - Te Mana
03-0531-0113530-001 (Please ref your FB name)
Support the dream:
Can’t perform? Come cheer, dance, and enjoy with great food & drink deals!

VIPs & judges will be on hand to spice up the night and crown our karaoke king/queen

Share this post, invite your crew, and flood the dance floor with love — the more, the merrier!
DJ & vibes:
DJ Mana spinning a vibrant mix of Pacific tunes for all ages
Epic lighting, dance circles, and island-flare vibes that’ll have you smiling all night
Why I’m asking for your help:
October tour in Australia is my first cricket adventure abroad — I want to represent our Tokelau family with pride.
Every dollar brings me closer to my dream and to stepping onto that pitch with heart!
Let’s make this night legendary. Your support means the world to me — bring family, friends, neighbours, and your best dance moves!
Special prizes for our male/ female best dressed outfit on the night

(Island Club Theme)
Hope to see you there!

He Kura Toi Tangata: Gold Card Tour, Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum invites our golden folk to experience an intimate, guided tour of photography exhibition He Kura Toi Tangata: 50 Years of the Waitangi Tribunal, 1975-2025.
The tour will continue throughout the museum, weaving through Wellington stories and taonga currently on display.
After the tour, we’ll sit down for a chat and a warm cuppa in the old Harbour Board room, with a little sweet something to finish off the afternoon.
This tour is part of the Takurua Hauora: Winter Wellness event series developed by Te Waka Huia Wellington Museum and is presented in collaboration with our programme partner Kāhui Legal.

Join Kelburn Community Garden and Seeds to Feeds on the last Sunday of every month at 11am for a volunteer working bee.

Tasks may include weeding, spreading mulch, and watering. As the newest community garden in Wellington, we need your help to get off the ground! We'll provide the tools, materials, and instructions. We're a friendly bunch who welcomes any and all to join. No experience needed.

We'll garden rain or shine, but we'll post on Facebook and have someone there at 11am if we need to cancel due to any weather warnings or hazards. Speaking of health and safety - please bring sunscreen, weather-ready clothes, robust shoes, and a water.

Hope to see you there!

description:
Karori Friendship Club, Looking for community, connection, and a good cuppa?

Come and join us at the Karori Friendship Club — a friendly weekly gathering where you can:
- Meet new people
- Share stories over morning tea
- Try your hand at a puzzle or join a chat group
- Simply enjoy time together in a relaxed space

Where: St Ninian’s Church, 208 Karori Road, Karori
When: Every Tuesday, 10am–12pm
Koha for morning tea

Although many who come are seniors, the club is open to anyone — whether you’re new to the area, a recent migrant, or just looking to make some new friends. People join us from all over Wellington, not just Karori!

Why not come along this Tuesday and see for yourself? You might leave with new friends, a full heart, and maybe even a completed puzzle.
label: Community & Culture

description:
International Day of the Girl - 2025, You are Invited to our inaugural International Day of the Girl Fundraising to celebrate the work of Heartprint Cambodia.

The AquaPura Project is raising funds for a new Safe Water installation, and an Emergency Rapid Response Kit for Heartprint in Cambodia.
Heartprint is wholly aligned with AquaPura's mission to educate and provide technical training for girls to be safe water system installers and maintenance leads, so they are provided an opportunity to succeed in a male-dominated industry of essential water provision services.

The theme of International Day of the Girl Child 2025 is:
"The Girl I Am, the Change I Lead: Girls on the Frontline of Crisis". 

This theme was developed in consultation with girls' organisations, UN partners, and girls themselves.

This theme emphasise the leadership potential of girls and their role in driving positive change, particularly in the face of crisis. 

The International Day of the Girl, observed annually on 11th October, aims to highlight the challenges girls face globally, and promote their rights and empowerment. 

The 2025 theme specifically acknowledges the unique experiences and contributions of girls during times of crisis, recognising them as agents of change. 

This fundraiser will be led by Girls, who deeply understand the importance of delivering Safe Water for Every Child.
Heartprint is a not for profit organisation committed to improving living standards of underprivileged families in Cambodia. Heartprint takes a holistic approach to charity by building the Heartprint Community Centre. They are able to provide the support that looks at the whole family structure, not just the basic living needs, but also addressing their overall physical, emotional, social, and spiritual wellbeing.

SCHEDULE: Sat 4 October InPerson Venue
10-12pm: Room 2
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)
1 - 3 pm: Room 1
*Event Video Presentation
*Emergency Response Kit Display
*Fundraising Table:
(Collect Signed Limited Edition Marlborough and Aotearoa NZ photobooks)

description:
Letters Out Loud 2025, An evening of historical texts brought to life by famous voices. Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.  
Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, Jennifer Ward-Lealand,
This will be an evening of poignancy, laughter, and connection with Aotearoa New Zealand's past. 
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.  More information about these grants can be found here: Research Grant (turnbullfriends.org.nz)
Catering from 5.00, readings begin at 6.00, event concludes approx 7.15

description:
Letters out Loud 2025 — Part of Friends of the Turnbull Library Public Programme Series, A 1940 newspaper exhorted its readers to ‘write a letter! Take a little chunk of your heart and spread it over some paper; it goes, oh, such a long way!’
Letters out Loud will expose some of those heart-felt issues people addressed on paper in the past. Well-known personalities will read letters from the Alexander Turnbull Library Collections which reveal concerns, among other things:
* the oldest extant Māori letter, written and read by a child
* the ups and downs of farm life
* Yehudi Menuhin in the bath
* a Member of Parliament in love
* on board the sinking Wahine in 1968.
Brought to life by familiar voices
Letters out Loud will be an evening of historical texts brought to life by familiar voices. Come and enjoy an enlivening of the past that has many resonances for today. Speakers include Ngahiwi Apanui- Barr, Una Cruickshank, Tanea Heke, Michele Leggott, David O’Donnell, Karen O’Leary, Trevor Richards, Vaughan Slinn, and Jennifer Ward-Lealand.
Doors open at 5pm for drinks and nibbles, readings begin at 6pm.
Book your tickets
Tickets to this gala fundraising event include a souvenir programme and refreshments.
https://events.humanitix.com/copy-of-letters-out-loud
All profits go to support grants for research at the Alexander Turnbull Library. The Friends of the Turnbull Library (FOTL) offer grants of $20,000 available to scholars whose research involves the use of the collections of the Alexander Turnbull Library.
https://turnbullfriends.org.nz/research-grant/
label: Community & Culture

description:
XTrail Spring - Skyline Scramble, XTrail Spring - Skyline Scramble
The Skyline trails deliver a signature Wellington run — native bush, panoramic peaks, and rolling ridgelines. All 3 courses begin in the lush surroundings of Otari-Wilton’s Bush, New Zealand’s only native botanic garden, and wind their way up to the summit of Johnston Hill. The short course offers a rewarding climb and scenic descent, while the long course adds a little extra vert and extends your adventure along the iconic Skyline Track, with sweeping views over the city, coast, and beyond. With flowing trails and plenty of natural beauty, it’s a proper taste of Wellington’s wild backyard.

https://barefootxtrail.co.nz/
label: Sports & Fitness

description:
Mahi Ready Day, Are you job hunting at the moment? Are you fixing up your CV and not sure where to start?
Come along to Mahi Ready Day: A friendly, supportive, community-led event to help you build confidence and practical tools for finding work.
You can drop in any time between 10am and 2pm to chat with one of our helpful facilitators, or listen to a talk about career prepared-ness.
Everyone is welcome!
Timebank members can pay using time credits, and everyone else is welcome to contribute koha.
Workshops & stalls including (keep an eye on this event for more updates and a full programme!)
CV & Cover Letter help
Practice interviews
LinkedIn headshots
Style and clothing advice
Employment red flags to look out for
Online and tech support
Here's what's on (+more to be announced)
Here are some examples of what's on:
10:30am - 11.15am - Talk: Showcasing Your Strengths: Turning Skills and Experience into Employment
Job hunting can feel overwhelming, especially in this very tough market. This will be a relaxed, mana enhancing, practical session where you can ask questions in a safe environment. Angelique has hired people for over 30 years and will share insider tips on how to write a good cover letter, what makes a CV stand out and how to prepare for interviews.
11:30am-12pm - Talk: Employment red flags
Dhilum from Community Law Wellington and Hutt Valley will lead this session on what to look out for when it comes to employment, in particular for people in ethnic and migrant communities - including discrimination, unpaid wages and visa precarity.
12:30pm-1.10pm - Making a Living as a Freelancer
Roger has been working 'portfolio' for many years and prefers the freedom that this style of work provides. He has run workshops & coached 00's of people working in this way originally under the NEWORK Centre banner. He will share some tricks on how to find work & also to juggle several roles simultaneously.
10-11am & 1-2pm - Professional Headshots
Need a new LinkedIn profile pic? Starting a public facing role? Setting up a portfolio? David will be offering professional headshots and can make you feel at ease while taking a great photo of you!
10am-2pm - CV & Cover Letter Support
Get some advice and support on how to make your job application stand out in a crowd.NB: Bring a paper copy of your CV and Cover Letter, or make sure you can access it through your email account on one of our laptops.
10am-2pm - Practice interviews
Come and practice your interview skills with Lisa - a friendly, supportive face with years of experience interviewing job candidates.

description:
Meet Dr Hinemoa Elder – Ara, A Māori Guidebook for the Mind, Come and meet bestselling author Dr Hinemoa Elder as she introduces her new book, Ara: A Māori Guidebook of the Mind.
Dr Hinemoa will be speaking about how her experiences as a psychiatrist, mother, whānau member and descendant have informed her writing.

She’ll share Māori resources for thinking about thinking, and provide much-needed and practical life guidance for our local and global communities.

Hinemoa’s short talk will be followed by a Q&A with the opportunity to meet this inspiring wāhine, ask questions and have her sign your books.

Everyone is welcome at this free event.

We expect this one to be popular, so please RSVP to Hedley's Books if you can to help us manage numbers.
RVSP in store, email sales@hedleysbooks.co.nz or call/text 0272816421.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Kāpiti Crop Swap RAUMATI, Kāpiti Crop Swap RAUMATI
This invite is for Crop Swap in Raumati 🌱

Everyone is welcome to our CROP SWAP meetings!

1st Saturday of the month – Otaki (1-2pm)
2nd Saturday of the month – Raumati (1-2pm)
3rd Saturday of the month – Pukerua Bay (3-4)
4th Saturday of the month – Waikanae (2-3pm)

To be clear, at Crop Swap, we swap more than just crops! We share everything homegrown and homemade: Vegetables, fruits, herbs, plants, seedlings, flowers, seeds, baking, preserves, sauces, jam and all things yummy! You can also bring everything garden and kitchen related like empty containers, tools, labels, planting pots, worm juice, coffee grounds, gardening magazines, cook books, recipes, a SKILL…possibilities are endless.

The key is that this is a cashless event, no koha can offered or accepted.

This is generally how a Crop Swap will run:

1-1.30pm
• People arrive with their crops and put them out on the tables provided.
• You are then free to chat and mingle with your fellow garden enthusiasts, exchange tips, make new friends or just wait until it starts.

1.30-2.00pm
• We conduct a quick briefing outlining the guidelines for swapping.
• If there is not a lot of people, we can listen to anyone who wants to introduce their crop.
• Once everyone has placed their crops we like to do a Karakia to bless the kai. We want to emphasise our values regarding generous giving and mindful taking.
• We are an inclusive group and all members and sectors of our community are welcome.

2.00-2.30pm
• Close out, put away tables and clear the hall.

The meetings will be held regularly on the 2nd Saturday of every month.

Further information:
1. There will be a koha food box for anyone who wants to donate food or seedlings in addition to their swaps. The Crop Swap team will distribute any koha crop and left over crops to local food pantries.

2. If you do not have any crops to swap but need fresh fruit or veges for the next week, you can bring plants, flowers, seedlings, herbs, eggs, preserves, jams, baking, liquid manure, gardening books, magazines, planting containers, sometimes even chooks who need a new home! We want this to be accessible to everyone, especially those who are struggling to put fresh fruit and veges on the table!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland, Miramar Local History Event : Wonderland
Wonderland was Wellington’s first ever amusement park. Based in Miramar, it opened in 1907 and was located near the present-day Wētā Cave. At the time it was one of the biggest amusement parks in the Southern Hemisphere. Its various attractions were originally to be found at the New Zealand International Exhibition of 1906-1907 and were brought to Wellington after that exhibition closed. The park has a fascinating and interesting back story which the panellists will explore.

This very special event will be an unmissable treat for all local history buffs as well as a fabulous journey into Wellington’s and especially Miramar’s past, and features two of Aotearoa’s finest and most acclaimed historical novelists and Wellington City Libraries' own Local History Specialist.

Meet the panel:

Tracy Farr:
Tracy Farr's debut novel The Life and Loves of Lena Gaunt was long­listed for Australia’s Miles Franklin Literary Award, shortlisted for the Barbara Jefferis Award and Western Australian Premier’s Book Awards. Wonderland is her third novel and is set in and during the time of Miramar’s Wonderland.

Philippa Werry:
Multi-award winning historical fiction writer Philippa Werry’s most recent book Iris and me about the travels of Robin Hyde won the Young Adult Fiction Award at the NZ Book Awards for Children and Young Adults. Her numerous other works include award winning fiction, non-fiction, picture books, plays and poetry, with a special emphasis on children and young adults, and a particularly strong focus on Aotearoa / New Zealand stories and history.

And to complete our illustrious panel we have Wellington City Library’s Local History Specialist, Gábor Tóth.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

Marlborough Sports Awards 2025, Marlborough Sports Awards 2025
Join us for Marlborough's premier sports awards function. The 2025 live awards dinner, recognising all our nominees and winners.

About this Event



2025 Sport Tasman Marlborough Sports Awards
Saturday 22nd November. Marlborough Events Centre
6 pm meet and mingle, to be seated by 6.30pm.
The Marlborough Sports Awards is an opportunity to acknowledge some of our top sportspeople amongst family, friends and the wider community. The 58th annual Awards will take place at the Marlborough Events Centre at 6.00pm on Saturday 22nd November 2025.

Dress Code: Formal Dress Attire (no jeans please)
Join us in celebrating the success of Marlborough's leading athletes through to our grassroots heroes, and to recognise one person's lifetime contribution to sport when they are awarded the prestigious 'Marlborough Medal'.
MC: Our 2025 Masters of Ceremony will be returning back to his home stomping ground to provide some vibrant entertainment.Tony Lyall is one of Aotearoa's leading MC's with a background working in 7 Days, The Project, Radio Hauraki alongside his sporting success leading the Match Days for Black Caps, NZ Cricket and the Blues Rugby.
We have some exciting new categories for 2025!

Premier / National / International Awards
Emerging Young Talent of the Year (Under 19yrs) x 2
Sportswoman of the Year
Sportsman of the Year
Supreme Team of the Year
Overall Sportsperson of the Year

Aspiring / Regional / Awards
Community Team of the Year

Contribution / Recognition Awards
Marlborough Medal (Lifetime Contribution)
Community Heroes (5 winners)
Includes: A glass of wine or a beer on arrival, a family style dinner, two bottles of wine per table, non-alcoholic beverages and a fantastic evening of awards presentations and entertainment.
Doors open for pre-dinner function at 6.00pm Official start time: 6.30pm
Purchase individual tickets here (you can purchase up to 10 individual tickets). Students aged under 18 must be accompanied by a parent or guardian.
If you want to purchase a table of 10 contact Tasha Leov on if you prefer to be invoiced.

description:
National Library 60th Birthday Open Home, Here’s to 60 years! Your National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa is turning 60 and we’re opening our doors in Wellington to invite you, your whānau and communities to celebrate with us.
Come along to view our collections up close, take part in activities and join guided tours of the He Tohu exhibition and our collection stores.
Our curators, librarians, archivists and conservators will share some of their favourite collection items and take visitors behind the scenes of the Library. There will be tours of He Tohu, a chance to help build a replica waka and a kids’ corner to keep the whānau entertained. At 2pm, we’ll be celebrating with cake.
Our friends at City Gallery Wellington will be open from 1pm to 4pm.
Experience your taonga
View a display of our collections from the National Library and the Alexander Turnbull Library, featuring taonga from books, comics, manuscripts, photos and more.
Learn about what we collect, how we collect and how you can make the Library your whare through making the most of our services and connecting with our collections. Drop in to chat with Library staff, learn more about our work and get up close with the collections.
Build a waka with friends
Help build the replica voyaging waka Whakaura and learn how Māori and Pacific peoples used their knowledge and navigational expertise to sail their amazing waka across one-third of the earth’s surface.
***Join a guided tour***
Explore our back of house — Take a special guided tour of our collection repositories and learn more about how we preserve the cultural heritage of Aotearoa New Zealand. Don’t miss out on this very rare opportunity to take a peek behind the scenes and see some exciting taonga in our collection stores.
Tours are 45 minutes and booking is essential as spaces are limited. Please email us to reserve your place — events.natlib@dia.govt.nz.
***Take a tour of He Tohu***
No booking required. Join our friendly kaiārahi for a guided tour of our exhibition He Tohu and view the three iconic constitutional documents that are shaping Aotearoa New Zealand:
*1835 He Whakaputanga o te Rangatiratanga o Nu Tireni — Declaration of Independence of the United Tribes of New Zealand
*1840 Te Tiriti o Waitangi — Treaty of Waitangi
*1893 Women’s Suffrage Petition — Te Petihana Whakamana Pōti Wahine.
History of the National Library Te Puna Mātauranga o Aotearoa: The National Library was formed in 1965 when the General Assembly Library, the Alexander Turnbull Library and the National Library Service (comprising the Country Library Service and the School Library Service) were brought together by the National Library Act 1965. For the past 60 years, we’ve continued to grow and evolve our collections and services.

description:
NZ Sign Language - Introductory Level 1A, For beginners who have no prior knowledge of NZ Sign Language. Discounted fee of $109 for NZ citizens and residents - ID required.

Description
By the end of the course, you'll be able to communicate in basic sign language and will be able to:

- Introduce yourself, greet other people and exchange personal information
- Demonstrate strategies for: getting attention, asking for clarification, correction and repetition
- Demonstrate the finger spelling alphabet
- Use numbers (0 – 20) and simple time phrases
- Express basic needs and wants
- Use a basic signing vocabulary

Note: Courses need a minimum number to go ahead so if we don't have enough enrolments a few days before the start date, we have to cancel. We'll let you know by email so please check yours regularly. If you need to cancel your registration, here are our terms and conditions: "What You Need to Know".

Duration 8 weeks,
Ricki Pointon

description:
Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour - FULLY BOOKED
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations.

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.


Booking is REQUIRED
Cost: suggested koha $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/matai-moana-mount-crawford-historic-walking-tour/


Health & Safety
This is a walking tour with some uneven terrain. A reasonable level of fitness is needed. Please wear comfortable shoes and dress for the weather.

Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather. The tour may be cancelled in bad weather.

description:
The Bubble Spectacular, Get ready for a different sort of pop sensation. Enter the effervescent world of The Bubble Spectacular. Take warm water, liquid soap, glycerin, and the creative talents of Dr Hubble. With those simple ingredients, Dr Hubble conjures up a fun-filled bubbly world. Prepare to be amazed as the ultimate master of bubbles creates an amazing bubble world. There’ll be little bubbles, big bubbles, volcanic bubbles, tornado bubbles, square bubbles, and with a bit of bubbly-magic, you might even end up inside a bubble. 
Young and old will enjoy a bubble party filled with laughter, audience participation and even a little burst of fire. As bubbles fly around the auditorium, get ready to pop, bounce, and boogie in an unbubb-levably fun way. Catch it before it floats away.

We are volunteer run organisations but as with everything these days, the costs to continue are rising.

Please arrive by 6:30pm to get your tables, drinks and food, to be ready for a 7pm quiz start.
The emcee and quiz master for the night is up and coming Canadian (turned Wellingtonian) comedian Meaghan Fisher who will be sure to make you laugh!
