Open Mic Night at Eva, Eva Pub's Open Mic Night: A Celebration of Wellington's Finest Musicians!

Join us every Thursday night at Eva Pub for an unforgettable celebration of Wellington's vibrant music scene!
With an electrifying array of local talent and plenty of opportunities for you to shine, there's no better place to experience the magic of live music than your favorite local hangout.
When: Every Thursday
Time: 8:00 PM Onwards with DJ set from DKav after the open mic
Where: Eva Pub, 35 Dixon Street, 6011
What to Expect:
Local Talent Showcase: Our stage is open for musicians of all genres, offering a platform for both seasoned performers and emerging artists.
Supportive Atmosphere: Hosted every week, our Open Mic Night is more than just an event; it's a community. Our friendly host will help you settle in, assist with setup, and organize the sets to ensure a seamless and enjoyable experience.
Community of Creatives: Experience the warmth of a community that appreciates and supports local and new performances. Whether you're a regular or a first-timer, our stage welcomes you with open arms.

Join In or Enjoy as a Spectator: Whether you're a performer or a music enthusiast, our Open Mic Night is the perfect place to share your talent or simply enjoy a night of entertaintment.
Secure Your Spot:
Don't miss out! Reserve your spot now for Eva Pub's Open Mic Night
Let's make Thursday nights at Eva Pub the highlight of your week as we come together to celebrate the incredible music that our city has to offer. See you there!

description:
PALMERSTON NORTH - Regent on Broadway, PALMERSTON NORTH - Regent on Broadway
We invite you to join us for a night of Creedence Clearwater Revival and John Fogerty, as we celebrate the music of one of the world’s most iconic bands – from the songs they wrote, to the songs covered, to the songs they wrote for others.

From their album debut in 1968 to their last album in 1972, CCR was a juggernaut of phenomenal proportions.

No other band has created such an impact in such a short time.
The Creedence Clearwater Collective brings to the stage a band that captures the unique CCR sound.

You do not want to hear through the grapevine that you missed out on this fun, hit-packed live concert.

Join us, a real-life travelling band.

Ticket Link 👇
https://www.regent.co.nz/shows/creedence-clearwater-collective-2

description:
Over the Rainbow, Over the Rainbow
There’s no place like Pōneke.

Queer historian Will Hansen and legendary barman Malcolm Vaughan kōrero the capital’s vibrant LGBTQIA+ nightlife for Wellington Heritage Festival.


About Will

Will Hansen (he/him) is a transgender historian based in Pōneke. He is the recipient of a Judith Binney Trust Writing Award and is currently working on turning his PhD thesis – ‘Queer Activism in Aotearoa, 1961-2013’ into a book. Will is also a trustee of Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa.


About Mal

Malcolm Vaughan is a Wellington gay icon. Before the Homosexual Law Reform Act of 1986, Mal worked at a series of bars and late-night haunts in the capital. More than just places to drink, venues like The Dominion, Bamboo Bar, Casper’s, The Dome (to name a few) provided a safe place in the capital for the city’s rainbow community to meet without prejudice. Today, Malcolm alongside husband, Scotty Kennedy ow and run the iconic Cuba Street establishment Scotty & Mal’s Cocktail and Lounge Bar.

Advocates for many LGBTQIA+ causes, they have supported many community initiatives over the years. In 2000 they co-founded the After Life Memorial Trust, now called the Chrissy Wītoko Memorial Trust, which originally provided financial support for AIDS patients of the rainbow community. The Trust continues to provide a wide range of support for the Wellington rainbow community.
label: Community & Culture

description:
PANEL TALK: BALLROOM CULTURE, Ballroom is a queer subculture. The Ballroom scene today was created by Black and Latinx trans women in the late 1960s in Harlem, New York. Since then, ballroom has taken over the world with scenes in Europe, Asia, Africa, South America and Oceania.
The Aotearoa Ballroom scene was ignited by Māori and MVPFAFF+ youth in Tāmaki Makaurau over 10 years ago, and has since inspired other leaders across the motu to forge their own Ballroom communities in their respective cities. 
In preparation for The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball, hear from influential figures who have made significant contributions to their own scenes. With international Icons and Legends coming to Aotearoa for the first time, there has never been a better time to learn and enhance our own knowledge and experience of Ballroom. 
Featuring ballroom leaders Arturo Mulan (NYC, USA), Matyouz Royalty (Paris, EU), Jaycee Iman (Auckland, NZ), Karamera Marama and Romé Marama.
Panellists
Icon Arturo Mulan (NYC Father of the International House of Miyake-Mugler) (he/him) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the beating heart of Ballroom, NYC. Arturo has been involved in Ballroom since 1996 and has established himself as a visionary choreographer and community leader, with the title of NYC father of the international mainstream House of Miyake Mugler. His influence spans competitive wins, global workshops, and has dedicated his time to bringing diverse artistry into ballroom culture, and ballroom culture into diverse arts opportunities; such as Legendary - Season 2 (HBO Max), Brooklyn Nets performances, Cats the Jellicle Ball on Broadway and more.
Icon Tantine Matyouz Royalty (International Godmother of the International House of Gorgeous Gucci) (he/she/they) is a ballroom Icon and Legend from the Paris Ballroom scene and is the creator of the ‘Fashion Killa’ category. They discovered voguing and ballroom culture in 2009 during a trip to New York which they believe changed their life. Their impact within ballroom spans several categories: Commentator vs Commentator, Hands Performance, Runway and Fashion categories. Matyouz has become a staple commentator and music artist within the ballroom community, with a repertoire of modelling and influencer opportunities in their resumé.
Legendary Overall Founding Mother Jaycee Iman aka Jaycee Tanuvasa (she/her) is an inter-disciplinary Sāmoan artist and choreographer of fa’afafine, femme queen & trans experience. Born and raised in South Auckland, Tāmaki Makaurau, her work is firmly rooted in community as she places autonomy and story sovereignty at the core of each of her projects. She celebrates the fullness of young, queer, brown life and works collaboratively to create empowering and responsive reflections of this across a range of media such as theatre, film and activations.
Founding Mother Karamera Marama (he/they) is an emerging multi-disciplinary, queer and Māori artist professing in Graphic Design, Dance and Performance Arts. They are the Co-Founding Mother of the trailblazing Kiki House of Marama, Co-Director of Pōneke-based queer arts collective OVĀ and member of the Aotearoa Ballroom council. Karamera has been involved in Ballroom since 2020 competing in Performance and Fashion categories and winning numerous grand prizes across Aotearoa & so-called Australia respectfully; most notably within Vogue Fem categories.
Founding Mother Romé Marama (he/him) whakapapa to Ngāti Porou, Ngāti Kahungunu, Ngāti Hineuru, and Ngāti Tūwharetoa. He is an emerging multi-disciplinary performing artist, as well as the Co-Founding Mother of the House of Marama and Co-Founding Director of OVĀ. For the past five years, he has been a prominent figure in Aotearoa Ballroom, both competing and facilitating events. Renowned in the RUNWAY category, Romé has secured multiple Grand Prize titles across Aotearoa and so-called Australia.
Facilitator: Kasi Marama (he/him/barb) 
Kasi Valu ('Eua, Ma'ufanga, Lapaha / Tonga) Full-Time sergeant of Gag city #Barbz Part-Time hater of the Rihanna #Navy and Casual staff member of the #Beyhive. Retired Hater of the #swifties and founding member of Azealia Banks support group. Actor, Writer, and Producer. His work currently centres on the experiences, wit, complexities, and universality of Pacific peoples, all whilst being an all-time fia botz, professional guesser and self-deprecating in this miserable world.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Paddy the Wanderer, Paddy the Wanderer
A dog’s eye view of Wellington waterfront history with Wellington Museum Senior Curator, Taonga, Ian Wards.

Bring your canine family member. Dog treats included!

Who was Paddy the Wanderer?

Paddy the Wanderer was a beloved Airdale Terrier known for roaming Wellington waterfront in the 1930s. After many adventures and years of dedication to the city’s maritime community, the Wellington Harbour Board bestowed Paddy the title of “Assistant Night Watchman in Charge of Pirates, Rodents and Smugglers.”

A life-sized statue of Paddy is proudly on display at Wellington Museum and the drinking fountain for dogs and their humans outside of the New Zealand Academy of Fine Arts is also dedicated to him.

Retrace Paddy’s pawprints and fetch fascinating stories with Wellington Museum’s history dog-walk.

Note: please bring socialised/trained dogs only. And don’t forget to BYO doggy-doo bags!

Walk begins at Wellington Museum and ends at Oriental Bay.

Sunday 19 October | 10am–12pm
Dogs go FREE

Tickets:

Adults: $20

Children: $12

Family of 3: $40

Family of 4: $55

description:
PJRC Quiz Night 2025, PJRC Quiz Night 2025
📣 𝐓𝐈𝐂𝐊𝐄𝐓𝐒 𝐎𝐅𝐅𝐈𝐂𝐈𝐀𝐋𝐋𝐘 𝐎𝐍 𝐒𝐀𝐋𝐄! 🎉

Back by popular demand after last year’s sell-out success, Paraparaumu Junior Rugby Club’s Annual Quiz Night is returning in 2025!

✨ Theme: Fame Game – come dressed as someone famous and see if the crowd can guess who you are!
✨ When: Saturday 20th September 2025
✨ Where: Paraparaumu Rugby Clubrooms
✨ Tickets: $40 per person (includes 1 free drink + nibbles)
✨ Entertainment: Quiz, mini-games, spot prizes, best dressed comp, and a live band to finish the night!
💛 All profits go directly to helping fund our Junior Rugby Teams 💙

⚠️ Spaces are limited — tables will sell fast!
👉 Grab your tickets now at: https://www.trybooking.com/nz/ZAJ

💛💙 More than just a rugby club — it’s a community!

Book Launch, Book Launch
Join Minky and Elaine to celebrate the launch of the first book in a brand new picture book series brought to you by Scholastic NZ - Keith vs Queenie.
There will be talks from the author and illustrator, live music, crafts for the kids, food, drinks, and a bedtime story.
Everyone welcome

description:
Pregnant As - Couples Hangout Wellington, Meet other expecting mums and dads at our next couples hangout on Tuesday 19th August! 🤰✨
Our sessions vary each time but expect a guided discussion, a fun pregnancy themed activity, and some casual time to mingle. Not to mention tasty 0% drinks and bump-friendly snacks on us!
Pregnant As sessions are suitable for first timers to veteran parents and you can attend at any stage in your pregnancy.
Try your first sessions for half price using the code: HALF-OFF ✨
Check out the website for further information or shoot us a message through Email or Facebook.
Location
📍 Undercurrent, Tory Street, Wellington
🗓 Tuesday 19th August | 6pm - 7:30 PM
Have Questions or Need More Info?
Feel free to reach out!📩 Email: pregnant.as@gmail.com💬 Facebook: facebook.com/pregnant.as

label: Community & Culture

description:
Wellington Writers Walk walking tour, Walk the Walk – explore the iconic Wellington Writers Walk on a gentle, guided waterfront walking tour
The much-loved Wellington Writers Walk consists of a series of 23 quotations from well-known New Zealand writers. This walking tour, led by members of the Writers Walk committee, will provide an opportunity to find out more about its history, discover some of the sculptures and ask questions. It concentrates mostly on the sculptures in the area around Te Papa and Te Wharewaka.

Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $20
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/.../wellington.../
label: Community & Culture

description:
Practices of Compassion, Explore the practices of the Sisters of Compassion then and now, through the lens of the historic crèche and the ongoing mahi of the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Learn about the historic crèche established by Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert and the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, now known as the Pukeahu Education Centre. Hear the stories of the practices of compassion led by the Sisters in early 20th century Wellington.

Then, walk over to the Compassion Soup Kitchen on Tory Street where the Sisters of Compassion and their co-workers are still supporting people with kai, aroha and much more.

This programme offers a unique look at the past and present practices of compassion emanating from these two influential and historic Wellington sites. Please bring along a cash koha for the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

Session times:
Wednesday 22 October 12pm — 1:30pm
Thursday 23 October 12pm — 1:30pm

Booking is required.

The Compassion Soup Kitchen is a two-minute walk from the Pukeahu Education Centre.
Please wear good shoes and dress for the weather.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Wellington Pop-Up, Saturday 23rd of August to Sunday 7th of September, head to our annual Wellington Pop-Up sale. We'll have a range of clearance items along with our regular range of top performing NZ made gear.
Monday-Saturday: 9am-6pm
Sunday: 10am-4pm
See you there.
label: Markets & Fairs

description:
Youth Beginner Watercolour Class - Kapiti Summer, In this 2 hour art class, youth will enjoy painting their own masterpiece whilst guided through the secrets of watercolours by a master artist in a fun step by step teaching style. Attending one of the art classes above Petone’s seaside art & gift gallery could be one of the most enjoyable and rewarding activities youth could do these holidays. After each 2 hour lesson they’ll have a completed painting to be proud of and wearing a beaming smile of creative satisfaction.

The $25 fee includes all materials supplied including quality watercolour paper. Suitable for ages 7 – 17

No previous art experience is required, suitable for both beginners and artists who’d like to fine tune their skills. Don’t worry about drawing as this will be done so we can focus on the joys of watercolour painting.

Check out other classes, each has a different subject to choose from, Also available are Saturday family art classes as well as Wine & Watercolour evenings on Friday and Saturday evenings.
label: Classes & Workshops

description:
REVELRY - Celebrate Footnote at 40, REVELRY - Celebrate Footnote at 40
Footnote New Zealand Dance are celebrating 40 years of daring, world-class, trailblazing contemporary dance.

40 years of connecting communities, pushing the boundaries, and uplifting Aotearoa’s artists. In 40 years, Footnote New Zealand Dance has created 100 works, and employed 100 company dancers. That’s a lot to celebrate, and we want to celebrate it with you.

Come join us for a night of boisterous festivity and unrestrained merrymaking.

What’s an arts event without a bit of fundraising? Curated just for Revellers, our Silent Auction is packed full of goodies. Bidding is open soon, and will close at the end of the night.

Entertainment for the evening provided by the fabulous Chocolate Box (Vanessa Stacey & Lisa Tomlin)

Bubbles and canapés on arrival. Cash bar serving tipples and treats all evening.

Early Bird tickets available till 14th August!
label: Community & Culture

description:
Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion, Rainbow Elders: Our Aspirations, Our Well-Being, Our Rights - a panel discussion
Te Kāhui Tika Tangata Human Rights Commission is proud to host this discussion for International Day of Older Persons in partnership with Kawe Mahara Queer Archives Aotearoa (formerly LAGANZ).

Panelists from the Wellington rainbow community - 𝗠𝗮𝗻𝗶 𝗠𝗶𝘁𝗰𝗵𝗲𝗹𝗹, 𝗞𝗲𝘃𝗶𝗻 𝗛𝗮𝘂𝗻𝘂𝗶 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝗟𝗮𝗶𝗻𝗲𝘆 𝗖𝗼𝘄𝗮𝗻 - will join Chief Commissioner Dr Stephen Rainbow for the discussion and a brief Q and A session. 🌈🎙️💫

Prudence Walker, Disability Rights Commissioner and Rainbow rights spokesperson will host the panel.

𝗣𝗿𝗲-𝗿𝗲𝗴𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗿𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻 𝗶𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗾𝘂𝗶𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗼𝗿 𝘁𝗵𝗶𝘀 𝗳𝗿𝗲𝗲 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗻𝘁 𝗱𝘂𝗲 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝗺𝗶𝘁𝗲𝗱 𝘀𝗲𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗻𝗴. Pre-register here: https://events.humanitix.com/rainbow-elders-our-aspirations-our-well-being-our-rights-a-panel-discussion 🎟️🎟️🎟️

The discussion runs from 10.30am to 11.30am.

NZSL will be available. The venue is accessible.

Light refreshments will be available.

A recording of the discussion may be made available afterwards via the Commission's website.
❤️🧡💛💚💙💜🩷

Network & Connect: Wellington December, It’s time for the Sustainable Business Network Wellington community to get together for our final coffee catch-up of 2025! 
This is an SBN investor-only event.
Join us to celebrate the start of summer, share your sustainability stories from 2025, and look ahead to 2026. 
You’ll have the chance to shout-out about what’s been happening in your organisation, we’ll provide an update on the latest at SBN. That will include reflections from the Next Fest and Sustainable Business Awards. 
As always, this will be a great opportunity to meet other organisations in the network and form new connections in a welcoming and informal setting.
Our December event will be hosted by RNZ.
Not a SBN Impact Investor (member) and want to know about joining the network? Please email us at investor@sustainable.org.nz.

description:
SS Hikitia Steam Crane Showcase and Ship Tours, SS Hikitia Steam Crane Showcase and Ship Tours
Come see a nearly 100-year-old steam crane in action! The Hikitia and her crew will be operating a floating crane to showcase technology from the age of steam

You may already know the SS Hikitia as one of the world's oldest floating steam cranes, but did you know that the crane still works?

Our dedicated group of volunteers will be undertaking demonstration lifts with Hikitia’s crane and also opening the ship for tours.

Come see what it takes to operate a heavy piece of lifting equipment from the golden era of steam!


Cost: Koha
Event information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/ss-hikitia-steam-crane-showcase-and-ship-tours/


Health & Safety
During operation of the crane there will be no members of the public on board the vessel, an exclusion zone set up around the ship, and a crew member on the wharf side providing commentary about the ship and the operations.

During ship tours, there will be 2 tour guides with each group (maximum of 10 people per group) and a full H&S induction will be undertaken. The ship is equipped with first aid equipment and one of the guides will be first aid trained.
label: Community & Culture

description:
September Full Moon Drumming, Please remember this is a ZERO WASTE and *NO ALCOHOL* community gathering.
Kia ora!
Full Moon Drumming Wellington is a registered public event with the Wellington City Council. We are a group of humans from all walks of life who gather under the full moon each month to connect through drumming and dance around the fire. This gathering is participatory, that means if you made it to the circle you are part of the circle. As in Africa, there is no audience! Everyone is invited to participate as part of the ‘chorus’ (singing/clapping), dancing, or drumming.
The event is weather permitting, we check the forecast a few days prior and aim to make a decision the day before the event, although this is not possible and sometimes we make the decision on the day. All updates are posted on the event page.
This gathering is entirely run by volunteers, if you'd like to contribute in any way please get in touch.
There are a few things that we need help with:
- FIREWOOD: Please bring dry firewood as a koha, no wood no fire! Please NOTE we DO NOT burn pallets (due to nails) or treated timber. Driftwood from nearby south coast beaches is often abundant, feel free to post or reach out if you have a vehicle and are keen to help gather firewood on the day of the event.
- BEAUTIFYING THE CIRCLE SPACE: Anyone has fairy lights, oil burners, or is keen to make some signs?
NOTE: We hold a fire permit for this event. For safety reasons we don't allow participants to feed the fire, and while is generally okay to roast some marshmallows early in the evening we don't allow the use the fire for cooking or heating food.
This is an **ALCOHOL FREE EVENT**, please help us uphold this kaupapa and remind those who are unaware and might be new to the event. As hosts we are responsible for your safety and we take that responsibility seriously, especially given that the event is authorised through both fire and event permits. Large, public, all ages gatherings require administration and logistics so please respect this and the guidelines provided.
Princess Bay is within Taputeranga Marine Reserve (https://octopus.org.nz/taputeranga-marine-reserve), we are welcomed to gather each month in this special place so let’s all make sure there is NO RUBBISH LEFT BEHIND and that we take care of the space. Dogs are NOT ALLOWED at the gathering - there are Korora (Blue Pinguins) nesting under the rocks nearby and we've had issues with dogs in the past.
Children are welcome at the fire, though, especially after dark, please make sure that all children have adult supervision, that the supervisors are aware of the children they are looking after, and that the children are aware of who is looking after them.
Feel free to bring:
- Your friends.
- Drums or any percussive instrument.
- Warm clothing; jackets and wool blankets are good.
- Something to seat on (otherwise sand is often wet)
- Drinking water.
- Food, tea to share.
- Your lovely selves.
- Fire spinning kit and fuel.
FIRE SPINNERS: Please take all precautionary safety measures and make sure to set up fire-spinning downwind from the fire circle.
PARKING: There's a parking lot a few hundred meters from the fire circle where there's also public toilets. Please also be aware of our neighbors driveway opposite the stairway and do not park directly in front of it.
CARPOOLING: If you don't have a way to get to Princess Bay, or if you have spare seats in your car, feel free to post it on the event page. The less cars driving the better.
Feel free to share the event page and send an event invite to whomever you feel would be interested, not everyone sees the notifications and advertising
label: Community & Culture

description:
SPANK, SPANK
SPANK is happening — and it’s going to be something special!

This isn’t your average dance party — it’s a kinky night with dancing, a dark room, the St. Andrew’s Cross, and more. We’ll have kinky costumes, a spectacular VJ, and a great DJ setting the mood all night long. And this time, we’re making it even better by opening up opportunities for the community to be part of the action.

We’re inviting members of the kink community to submit their own acts, scenes, or performances — whether it’s an amateur kinky act, exhibitionism, or something they’re excited to share in a safe, supportive environment. No professional acts — just real community energy and creativity.

Want to get involved? Send your ideas and scene proposals to by 31 July. This is your chance to be part of something exciting and make SPANK a night to remember!

Ticket link (Only people with the ticket link can find this event)
label: Community & Culture

description:
Sip & Connect: A Chai-Coffee Morning for the Assam Community – Round Three!!, Nomoskaar Raiz,
Due to popular demand, we’re brewing up another Coffee & Chai Catch-Up! Whether you’re a tea aficionado or a coffee enthusiast, come join us for another round of warm drinks, great company, and even better conversations.
Event Details:
📅 Date: 14th Sep 2025 (Sunday)
⏰ Time: 10:00 AM – 12:00 PM
📍 Locations:
Auckland: Shubh Restaurant and Takeaways, 520-524 Sandringham Road, Sandringham
Wellington: Tandoori Dhaba, 5 Mark Avenue, Paparangi, Wellington
Christchurch: TBA
What to expect:
✨ More lively conversations and lots of laughs
✨ Fresh stories , plus some new coffee & tea puns to keep things brewing
✨ A welcoming space to reconnect and make new friends in our Axomiya community
Please RSVP so we can save your seat and keep the good vibes flowing!
Whether you missed the first catch-up or want to relive the fun, we can’t wait to see you there. Let’s sip, chat, and celebrate our shared love for tea, coffee, and community!
Warm Regards,
Assam Society of New Zealand
label: Community & Culture

description:
Site Visit - Wellington Airport Fire Station, Join us for an exclusive behind-the-scenes look at the new Wellington Airport Fire Station, currently under construction by Naylor Love. This purpose-built facility is designed to support future air travel and will enhance the airport’s emergency response capabilities, replacing the existing station on the eastern side of the runway.
📍 Location: Wellington Airport Fire Station, Coutts Street, Rongotai
📅 Date: Friday, 5 September 2025
⏰ Time: 3:30 PM – 4:30 PM (arrive at 3.15pm)
🎟️ Tickets: FREE – but limited to 20 NAWIC members only
🛠️ What You’ll See and Hear About:
Importance Level 4 Building
Challenges of designing and building in an airport environment
Sustainable features of the build
Landscape improvements and viewing areas
💬 Why You Should Come
👷‍♀️ Learn from an active, high-profile infrastructure project
🧯 Gain insights into the unique requirements of an airport fire station build
🤝 Network with fellow NAWIC members and industry professionals
🛠️ See how construction is adapting to new aviation technologies
🦺 PPE requirements (hard hats, hi-vis, glasses, steel-capped boots). We have spare hi-vis, hard-hats and safety glasses available – please advise us in your RSVP if you require any help with this.
This is a NAWIC members-only event with limited capacity — please book your space consciously! 
🙏 A special thank you to Wellington Airport and Naylor Love for generously hosting this site visit and supporting women in construction.
We look forward to seeing you there! 🚒
Please note: NAWIC is a voluntary organisation, committed to its obligations as a PCBU under the Health and Safety at Work Act 2015.   Amongst other things, this requires NAWIC to take all practicable steps to eliminate, isolate or minimize hazards that our event attendees are exposed to. Health and safety is a shared responsibility.
label: Community & Culture

description:
Wellington Walk the Waterfront, Wellington Walk the Waterfront
Top Up Together

As part of Mental Health Awareness Week’s Be Active day, the Aotearoa Mental Health Collective invites you to join us for an evening of movement, connection and community.
We’ll gather at The Lounge at St John's Bar, Wellington from 5.30 pm for a warm welcome and a chance to connect. Then at 6 pm we'll take a walk along the beautiful Wellington waterfront, returning to The Lounge at St John's around 6.45 pm.
After the walk, you’ll have the opportunity to share a meal or snacks of your choice, deepen connections, and continue the conversation in a relaxed setting. As this is a free event, you’ll order and pay for any food and drinks yourself and can choose from the wide range on offer at St John's Bar.
Walking alongside others and taking the time to connect can boost our wellbeing, reduce stress, lift our mood and strengthen our sense of belonging.
Spaces are limited, so secure your spot today.
We look forward to connecting, walking and topping up our wellbeing together this Mental Health Awareness week.

With thanks to St John's Bar, who have generously provided the venue for this free event.
label: Health & Wellness

description:
THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL, The Trailblazing Kiki House of Marama present THE GRAND KIKI HOUSE OF MARAMA BALL 🌙
Proudly supported by OVĀ Collective and Te Papa Tongarewa.
The Grand Kiki House of Marama Ball will celebrate five years of the Kiki House of Marama excellence and the legacy of the growing Wellington Ballroom scene.
Join us for a night of high-energy performances and out-of-this-world fashion as walkers compete for trophies and prizes in a display of Black and Brown queer and trans joy, liberation, and Ballroom* artistry.
With a fabulous line-up of Categories, Judges, Commentators and DJ, including major local and international Ballroom figures, we invite you to wear your best outfits and prepare to finger snap ✨ 🤏 dance 💃 and cheer 🥳 the night away at Te Papa Tongarewa on Sat 4th Oct.
Ballroom Community Walkers & Spectators Ticket Access
Contact our House account on Instagram @houseofmarama or your local Ballroom leaders for the access codes to Ballroom Community Spectators & Walkers tickets.
There is a discount code for Fem Queens FREE access for FQ who are not walking/competing, please contact us or your local leaders for the discount code.
Categories & Themes
Virgin Vogue - A Marama Storm (Treasure)
Bizarre - Nocturnal Creatures of Folklore
Realness (FQ, TM and BQ) - Date Night Under the Moonlight
Hands Performance - Memoirs from Mother Marama
Body (Slim, Thicc and Luscious) - Heavenly Bodies
Butch Queen Vogue Fem - A Marama Storm (Pirates)
Face (FF, MF and GNC) - Beauty of the Blood Moon
OTA Best Dressed - Once in a Blue Moon
Commentator vs. Commentator - Echoes of the Moon
Femme Queen Performance - A Marama Storm (Mermaids)
OTA Runway - The Phases of Marama
House of the Night (no theme)
Judges, Commentators & DJ announcement coming soon...
Please do not hesitate to contact us via houseofmarama@gmail.com or on all social media @houseofmarama for any questions or concerns.
⎯
Ballroom* is a safe space created in the 1960's, forged by the Black, Latinx and queer Americans in protest against the racism and queerphobia that they faced from the non-queer community and white queer community. It is a space held to protect trans womxn of colour, so as guests and participants within this culture it is imperative that we all do our best to respect and honour this sacred space. Homophobia, Transphobia, and any discriminatory language and/or beliefs will not be tolerated. Remember to check your privilege at the door.
To learn more about the culture of Underground Ballroom check out this link: https://artsandculture.google.com/project/ballroom. Be sure to check out the growing Wellington Ballroom scene and community by following @houseofmarama and @ova_collective on Instagram.
label: Community & Culture

description:
THREE JOYFUL HOUSES - AOTEAROA FESTIVAL OF ARCHITECTURE - SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER, THREE JOYFUL HOUSES by IAN ATHFIELD
SUNDAY 28TH SEPTEMBER @ FUTUNA CHAPEL - KARORI
Three joyful houses, three families and three client stories about the commissioning, designing, building and living in homes designed by Ian Athfield.
SPENCER and DIANE LOGAN
1974 - 1978
WINDY POINT – EASTBOURNE
Photographer unknown
Spencer Logan and his wife Diane will talk about the commissioning of their first new home, its design, construction, the cleaning of thousands of bricks, and living in this unique collection of a pair of recycled brick towers with timber clad ‘saddlebags’. 
ROSS, CUSHLA and TESS JAMIESON
1974 - 1978
MAHINA BAY
Ross and Cushla have lived in their home on the Eastern hills above Mahina Bay for 48 years. They will, along with their youngest daughter, recount their experiences of working with Ian Athfield in the commissioning of the design of their home, the construction process and then living in this hillside hugging collection of building, and how this home may have influenced their living and the raising of a family of four children.
JONATHAN CUSTANCE   - THE CUSTANCE HOUSE 1981 – 1982
HAVELOCK NORTH
“The Custance House replaced an early modern home that burnt to the ground in 1981 leaving only the swimming pool unscathed.  Ray and Ann Custance, who were friends of the Athfields, sought a bold replacement.  With their son, industrial and interior designer Jonathan Custance, they prepared a four page brief for a new building….. “
Text taken from Athfield Architects by Julia Gatley 2012 AUP.
The Trust looks forward to welcoming architects, designers, graduates, students and interested members of the public to attend this event and support the Trust in its work.
The Futuna Trust is a charitable organisation and all funds raised from the Futuna Lecture Series go towards the ongoing care, maintenance and operation of Futuna Chapel and also to support various initiatives undertaken by the Trust. 
BOOKINGS ARE ESSENTIAL TO ATTEND THIS EVENT
There will be 15 Design CPD points available for NZ registered architects attending the event. Please include your NZRAB registration number when registering for Architect tickets

description:
A Special School Holiday Screening: The Lost Tiger, This spring, the Māoriland Hub turns into a cosy little theatre for seven weeks of kiriata and kōrero. From September to November, a selection of Thursdays will be your chance to slow down, sink into a beanbag, sit back in a chair, and lose yourself in the magic of cinema. Bring your own pillow and blanket if you wish! - Door sales available!

This one is our special School Holiday screening - something fun for you and the kids to do, and on a budget. Afterwards, we'll chat with Chantelle Murray about her processes in bringing to life The Lost Tiger and what it means for her as an Indigenous woman in film.

*The Lost Tiger Synopsis:*
Teo is a plucky young tiger and one of the last of his kind. Found abandoned and wearing a mysterious crystal necklace, he is adopted into a big, boisterous kangaroo family of travelling wrestlers. After receiving visions from an unfamiliar land, Teo must suddenly embark on an epic quest to reconnect with his heritage and save his homeland from the clutches of destruction. Features the voices of Rhys Darby (Flight of the Conchords), Celeste Barber (Runt), and Thomas Weatherall (Heartbreak High).

description:
Water Casting - Spring, This is a super quick 3-hour session, and is great fun to do with family or friends.
Water casting is a really hands-on low-tech casting method that results in surprising and fun little forms that can be turned into pendants with amazing textures and shapes.
You will be guided through melting silver and pouring it into water to create little charms.
Experiment with pouring at different heights to create different shapes.
Choose one or a few of your favourites to have drilled and turn into simple pendants or earrings, or new charms for your bracelets!
We will use hardened jump rings to attach your water-cast pieces to either colourful cord or you can choose sterling silver chains which you can purchase for extra.
The technique will be demonstrated with important health and safety practices, then students will be guided to do at least a couple of casts, and should expect to have at least one successful item to clean up and finish in the class.
A basic amount of metal allowance of a small amount of silver is included in your course costs, and if your projects go over that amount you can pay for the metal you use on the day via internet banking or cash.
This course is open to complete beginners and advanced makers. Extra materials such as chains and findings are available to purchase.
For health and safety reasons class participants must wear sturdy, closed toe shoes and have their hair tied back.
Workshop fee $128, Early bird $115 till 17 August.
label: Classes & Workshops

They perform a fast-paced danceable set of blues tunes along with many of the tunes from the One Fine Day and Chasing the Gazelle albums.
Both albums feature a number of personal, not self-indulgent, but highly musical and uplifting tunes.
Cuba Express is Patrick Bleakley on bass, Abe Bailey on drums and Geoff Culverwell on trumpet and keys.
Bullfrog Rata has performed with many well-known acts including Midge Marsden and The Chills, international blues acts like Taj Mahal, Watermelon Slim as well as mega stars Tina Turner, Charlie Pride, and Jethro Tull.

Beehive to Business with Hon. Simon Watts, Join us on Thursday 18 September for our next Beehive to Business event with Hon Simon Watts, Minister of Climate Change, Minister for Energy, Minister for Local Government and Minister of Revenue.
With local Government decision making in the spotlight as we head into local body elections, there is no better Minister in the Government to hear from than Minister Watts.
Minister Watts is at the forefront of some of New Zealand’s most pressing issues – be it the energy market, water service delivery, or taxation, the decisions Minister Watts heads up are pivotal to New Zealand – and your business.
A recent Cabinet promotion, Minister Watts is seen as a critical cog in the executive Government – a chance to engage with the Minister on the issues that matter to you most is not to be missed.
This event is part of an ongoing series made possible by our partnership with premier consulting firm Allen + Clarke. Proudly based in Wellington, Allen + Clarke is equally at home advising the Beehive or business alike.

description:
Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse, Visit the Upper Hutt Blockhouse
This Heritage New Zealand Pouhere Taonga property is not open to the public often, so bring the family between 11am and 1pm.

Visit Upper Hutt Blockhouse as part of the Wellington Heritage Festival 2025.

The Upper Hutt Blockhouse is one of the few remaining buildings associated with the New Zealand Wars, as well as a monument to Pākehā settler anxiety, built in fear of an attack by Māori that never came.

Visit today and you’ll get a sense of the defensive ‘last stand’ mindset. On both floors you’ll find a series of balistraria, tightly angled gun slots through which members of the militia would defend their posts.

Keep an eye out, too, for an exposed panel where you can see the fine gravel that was packed between the exterior weatherboards and inch-thick interior boards to absorb the impact of answering gunfire. Don’t be fooled by the windows – they were added later. Originally, the loop holes you’ll spy on the walls were the only way to see out.

Inside the Blockhouse, there’s an exhibition from Whirinaki Whare Taonga, telling the early story of Upper Hutt and its Blockhouse.

We will have some knowledgeable people available to share stories, answer questions and some light refreshments. Drop in between 11-1pm and stay as long as you like!


Booking is REQUIRED.
Cost: $10 - $15
Booking information here: https://wellingtonheritagefestival.co.nz/event/visit-the-upper-hutt-blockhouse/


Health & Safety:
Please note as an historic building the Upper Hutt Blockhouse is not suitable for those with accessibility needs.
label: Community & Culture

description:
WSKN Christmas Event / SKISL, WSKN Christmas Event / SKISL
Hi everyone - welcome to the WSKN Christmas SKISL / Paddle to Mana!

On Saturday 13th December we will have a Christmas event on Mana Island, departing Titahi Bay at 10am (so arriving at 9:30) getting to Mana around 10:40, keen ones can do stuff prior to lunch around 12:00, then there might be groups that head back at different time slots, but we can work that out on the day. Return could therefore either be 1:30 or 2:30 with the latest return to Titahi Bay being 3pm.

We've made this event later than the normal SKISL so that it's easier for folks to drive down from Palmerston North, and also because it is a lunch event.

The lawn on Mana is really nice, sheltered and pleasant and there are also good walks. Mana is of course a sanctuary so you must check your boats for any wildlife especially ants that may have gotten in past the hatches. Also we cannot have any fires

Plan B: If weather nukes Mana, we'll try for Green Point or Onehunga Bay in Whitireia Park by driving there.

Plan C: We will postpone to 21 December

Crop Swap is a FREE heart-warming monthly community gathering to share what we have with each other. Think of it like a community garden potluck when each offering regardless of the amount adds up to a bounty.

Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share🌱

WHEN?
☕ Come along at 10:30am for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free @Peoples coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along.
Swapping kicks off from 11.00am.

WHERE?
You can find us in the community room on the ground floor of block C of the Newtown Park Apartments, 320 Mansfield St, Newtown, Wellington.

IDEAS OF WHAT TO BRING
🧡Bring a friend!
🍪Maybe you like baking?
🍋 Surplus lemons?
🌱excess seedlings
📖 Have garden books or magazines to destash?
🥬Too much silver beet going crazy?
🫘Left over seeds from summer to share?
💐Got some foraged flowers?

Crop Swap is the place for you!

description:
Voices from the Moana: Amplifying Pacific stories of healing and resilience, Talanoa Tai Learning is a new collection of learning experiences. They're designed to help you build your cultural responsiveness and improve your ability to engage meaningfully with Pacific communities. Talanoa is a Paciﬁc style of deep dialogue, with a focus on how we connect to each other and strengthen relationships, while still being able to share honest and eﬀective insights. Tai refers to ocean waters, which represent your opportunity to rise through the ebb and ﬂow of this learning journey. If you want to strengthen your capability in this space, to create transformational change, and to enhance your relationships with people from diﬀerent communities - this workshop is your chance to grow.
What will I gain from Voices from the Moana?
In Voices from the Moana, you will explore and share rich narratives of healing and resilience from different Pacific nations and perspectives. The Pacific ocean is a diverse place and we have our own unique stories of healing through traditional practices, beliefs and methods. This Talanoa Tai learning experience invites reflection on your own understanding of different healing modalities from the Pacific and the impact it has on your worldview. It will equip you to advocate for social justice through Pacific voices. You'll gain practical tolls and insights that you can apply directly to your work.
This is a 3 hour in-person learning experience.
Who is this workshop for?
These learning experiences are for both Paciﬁc professionals and those from other communities. You don’t need to have prior knowledge or experience in this area - we’ll meet you where you are and provide a welcoming, supportive environment for you to learn.
Cultural responsiveness is for everyone. Whether you’re in social work, education, government, community sectors or beyond, these learning experiences have been designed to help everyone build their skills. If you think this professional development might be right for you, it is!
Cost
When work is busy and budgets are tight, cultural responsiveness can often take a backseat. But this is an aﬀordable investment that will help you address the challenges that so many of us share, like how to build engagement and trust, and avoid relationship missteps. It’s not a buzzword; it’s a vital skill if you want to better meet the needs of the people you serve. Price: $170 (inc GST) per person, including morning tea.
 Facilitator
Our team’s extensive research and experience feed into these sessions, with a focus on interactive activities and practical, real-life examples. Our team has decades of experience across a range of ﬁelds, in particular social development, education, and research. We have worked with organisations and businesses across the Paciﬁc, and our engagement with diﬀerent Paciﬁc languages, cultures, and communities means we oﬀer robust, informed perspectives. Fa’aeafale’upolu (Polu) Samuelu is the facilitator of this Talanoa Tai Learning experience.

description:
HineHau Breathwork for Women, Join Shannon Rose for this unique three-hour breathwork workshop for all wāhine.

Through story, breath, and reflection, you’ll learn and experience the power of your breath as a wāhine: to cleanse, to create, and to consciously live in alignment with who you are.

Shannon has been immersed in the practice of breath since 2017 and is recognised as one of the pioneers of breathwork in Aotearoa. She is the founder of HineHau, a breathwork training kaupapa supporting wāhine to step into leadership and facilitation through the breath.

In this workshop, you’ll be safely guided on a journey of remembrance, reconnection, and reclamation. Expect to come away feeling grounded, rejuvenated, and more at home in your body.

What’s Included
*Karakia to open and close our space
*Purākau — Māori creation stories on the whakapapa of the breath
*Kōrero — how intentional breathing helps to align your mauri, wairua and mana
*Working with the nervous system to support manifestation and creativity
*BreathWav™ Journey — a 70-minute circular connected breath practice for release, alignment, and deep connection
*Journaling & Reflection to integrate what arises.

What to Bring
Water bottle, a journal + pen and an eye mask. Mats, blankets & supportive props provided.

Who This is For
This workshop is open to wāhine of all cultures who are ready to experience the healing power of Te Hā — the sacred breath.

description:
Sofa Session with Frida & Na'amah, See Frida Flacks and Na'amah Cheiban live in the comfort of Wellington's favourite community living room for an afternoon of harmonies, soul and original music.
~
Na’amah Cheiban is an Auckland-based singer-songwriter, session musician, teacher, and co-founder of Wāhine In Jazz. A graduate of the University of Auckland’s jazz programme, her music reflects the raw honesty of navigating relationships, faith, and mental health in her 20s. With solo guitar and soft, alluring vocals, she crafts intimate jazz-folk songs layered with lyrical melodies and intricate grooves.
~
Frida Flacks, a rising voice from Wellington’s scene, draws inspiration from artists like Lianne La Havas and Melody Gardot. A graduate of the New Zealand School of Music, she blends harmony, improvisation, and melodic textures to create performances that feel dreamlike and ever-changing.
~
After first collaborating at the 2024 Wellington Jazz Festival, Na’amah and Frida have built a close artistic bond. Their voices blend together like honey, offering audiences an experience both soulful and comforting—a warm embrace of harmony to start your festival weekend.

Thursday 4th September BOH 3.30 – 4.30PM

description:
Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026, Climate Action Week 2026 - Agenda
Dates: February 2026 - 23rd - 27th February
Theme: Leading by Doing: Local Businesses, Local Solutions, Collective Action
Each day features:
Morning: Local Business Story Sessions (Curated stories for our business community to get inspired with raw, honest and authentic stories)
Midday: Action Design Workshops (Crafting Plans & Solutions)
Afternoon: Immersion Experiences and Hands-On Field Visits (Applied Learning & Practical Support)
Day 1 - Water, Risk and Resilience 
Morning: Marlborough businesses facing water risks (horticulture, viticulture, manufacturing, nature, tourism) share adaptation stories: irrigation shifts, stormwater projects, water reuse innovations.
Midday: Business-specific water risks and trials of resilience-building solutions.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to diverse water initiatives across the region
Day 2 - Circular economy & waste
Morning: Circular leaders (including wine, food and beverages, building, construction, fisheries, nature) show how they have reduced waste, repurposed byproducts, or created new revenue streams from "waste."
Midday: Waste Challenge Mapping: Identify business-specific waste streams + select 1 trial action for next 6 months.
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to waste initiatives and innovative approaches across the region
Day 3 - Nature and Biodiversity 
Morning: Farmers, viticulturists & landscapers share regenerative planting, biodiversity corridors, and ecosystem services initiatives.
Midday: Biodiversity on Your Site Toolkit Workshop — Co-design biodiversity plans for business properties (guided by local ecologists & farming leaders)
Afternoon: Immersion experiences to nature, land and biodiversity initiatives across the region.
Day 4 - Energy & Carbon
Morning: Businesses share their real decarbonisation journeys: EV transitions, renewable installations, process efficiencies — including the unexpected savings, costs and impacts.
Midday: Carbon Reduction Sprints — Design quick-win carbon actions + long-term projects with support from energy consultants and local peers.
Afternoon: Site visits to Carbon and Energy initiatives across the region
Day 5 - Taking the courage to act
Morning: Businesses share how they initiated climate actions, including failures, lessons, and unexpected wins.
Midday: Climate Action Map Workshop — Business leaders build their tailored action roadmaps (guided by peers + facilitators).
Afternoon: Immersion to unique businesses focussed on climate resilience
Immersion Experience Hosts Confirmed
Yealands Estate Winery
Carbonscape
Wineworks
Climate Action Marlborough has had the support of Yealands Estate Wines from its inception and we are super grateful to have their support for Climate Action Week Marlborough 2026. They are committed to influencing the Marlborough business community, driving collaboration that impacts climate resilience, education, health and wellbeing of a thriving region and growing our regions expertise.

Conservation Week, Skink and Gecko Live Show Reino Grundling will talk and show slides illustrating the mostly unrealised role that lizards (skinks and geckos) had in our pristine ecosystems, with some 130 or more different species! And what makes this presentation so marvellous is that he will have a number of living examples there for all to see! Great for the kids!

Conservation Colouring Competition The Masterton Library is celebrating the importance of conservation with a colouring competition—and there are some great prizes up for grabs. There will also be an informative display featuring conservation-themed resources you’re welcome to take home with you.

Dr Marie Doole Biodiversity Funding Talk Dr Marie Doole will discuss the pros and cons around nature/biodiversity credits, an emerging option for funding the protection of biodiversity, particularly on private land, by investors, whether corporate or philanthropic. Worth attending if you've been following the media hype.

Think Like a Forest Film Forest and Bird are showing this film, starring Sam the Trap Man, in three locations. The Regent have generously offered to show it where it will have the most effect—on the big screen! The film is produced by Pure Advantage who have an aspirational programme around landscape-scale restoration of native forests called Recloaking Papatūānuku.

Kōkako Morning Hikoi Join us for a special one-off tour and experience the magic of the kōkako at Pūkaha. Follow our expert guide to a kōkako hotspot and enjoy the rare opportunity to possibly see and hear kōkako. After your walk, return to the centre for a hot drink and morning tea.

Waihinga Bridge Planting Morning Ruamāhanga Farm Foundation is hosting a morning of planting and a celebration of children's voices at the start of the soon to be opened Waihinga Bridge Walkway. Tools will be provided and all ages and abilities are welcome!

Exploring Ngahere Under Story and Campfire Talk The Tramping Gently Club Art Collective (TGCAC) takes up temporary residency at Te Whare Whakapapa Raranga to explore human-centred warning systems and ngahere's role in mitigating danger. Join us in bringing the understory into te whare through kōrero and creative exploration.

description:
Denniston - a place worth fighting for., The Denniston Plateau is one of Aotearoa's most unique landscapes and is rated by the Department of Conservation as a key ecologically valuable site. It is a unique ‘lost world’ ecosystem home to a remarkable array of life. A fast-track application to mine 20-million tonnes of coal in the area is expected to be filed this year.
Join us for an engaging session to:
Hear from experts about Denniston Plateau’s extraordinary biodiversity and ecology.
View a photo exhibition by West Coast photographer Neil Silverwood capturing the Plateau’s beauty.
Learn about the proposal to expand coal mining in the area
Wine, beer and appetisers are provided. You may be asked to show proof of identity upon arrival.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures, Designing Tomorrow: The SDG Blueprint for Built Environment Futures
📅 Wednesday, 1 October 2025
🕔 5:00–7:30 PM (Networking from 5:00 PM | Panels 5:30–7:30 PM)
📍 Te Aro Campus, Faculty of Architecture and Design Innovation, Victoria University of Wellington (139 Vivian Street)
The built environment is at the heart of Aotearoa’s response to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals SDGs). The way we plan, design, and construct our cities influences how we live — and how we tackle challenges such as climate change (SDG 13), sustainable cities and communities (SDG 11), affordable housing and equity (SDG 10),
responsible consumption and production (SDG 12), and partnerships for action (SDG 17).
This event is part of SDG Action Month 2025, a global campaign that highlights how communities, institutions, and industries are accelerating progress toward the 2030 Agenda.
For Aotearoa, the conversation is urgent: how can planning, design, and construction shape a sustainable, equitable, and climate-resilient future?
The evening will open with a keynote address that sets the stage with global perspectives on sustainability and the role of the built environment in achieving the SDGs.
Two panels will then explore critical themes:
• Planning + Place + People — equity, housing futures, cultural identity, indigenous leadership, and policy alignment.
• Materials + Methods + Innovation—construction technology, green standards, digital tools, and carbon-conscious practice.
Alongside the discussions, attendees can view a Student Showcase from the School of Architecture and the School of Design Innovation, and contribute to a Blueprint Wall by writing their own pledges on SDG Commitment Cards, ensuring the event concludes with collective action as well as ideas.
📌 Free to attend | Open to all | RSVP required

description:
Electrify Porirua: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Porirua will show you how.  
Most Porirua homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Porirua has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Porirua.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Porirua is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify Wellington: how to save money on your energy bills feat. Mike Casey, It keeps getting more expensive to heat our homes and water, cook our meals and get around. But there is a way to avoid those rising costs and Electrify Wellington will show you how.  
Most Wellington homes could be saving thousands on their energy bills each year, while also slashing emissions, simply by upgrading their gas and petrol machines to the electric equivalents available today - and ideally powering them with solar and batteries for more self-sufficiency in case of power cuts or natural disasters.
Wellington has crossed the “electrification tipping point” where homes, farms and businesses can now save money and reduce their emissions by going electric. It’s a massive win-win and a lot of people don’t know about the potential savings that are hiding in their cupboards, kitchens and driveways. 
Rewiring Aotearoa is trying to change that and we’re supporting grassroots action across the country. Community electrification groups are popping up all over the place and helping to raise awareness about the benefits for their local region and helping locals through the process. Now, it’s time to bring the buzz to Wellington.
Come along to hear from Mike Casey, who is saving tens of thousands a year on his all-electric solar-powered cherry orchard, and find out how electrifying Wellington is the smartest, cheapest, and healthiest way to power our lives.

description:
EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025, EBANZ Natural Building Conference 2025
This year’s EBANZ (Earth Building Association of New Zealand) national conference will see industry leaders, innovators and enthusiasts come together to profile the latest ideas, technologies and projects shaping the future of low carbon, high performing, sustainable building in Aotearoa.

Set at Te Wānanga o Raukawa and the Forest Lakes Conference Centre on the Kāpiti Coast, the earth building conference will see builders, designers, researchers and earth-building enthusiasts explore how traditional and contemporary earth construction methods are shaping resilient, sustainable futures in Aotearoa and beyond.

Themed ‘Earth, Culture and Community’, the three-day conference in mid-November will include presentations, hands-on workshops, site visits and kōrero with leading voices in natural building, indigenous knowledge, climate-responsive design and regenerative practice, while also profiling New Zealand’s own set of earth building standards (NZS 4297, 4298 and 4299) 2024.

A ‘Professionals Day’ on Friday 14 November at Te Wānanga o Raukawa is aimed specifically at architects, engineers, inspectors, builders and designers interested in earth and natural building techniques. It will dive into the Tennent Brown Architects-designed Pā Reo campus at Te Wānanga (a Living Building Challenge project) and presenters will include Rau Hoskins of designTRIBE, Verena Maeder of Solid Earth and Sigi Koko, founder of Build Naturally USA.

Friday will be followed by the in-depth weekend conference at Forest Lakes, featuring talks and presentations aimed to inform and empower people on different aspects of earth and natural building as well as hands-on workshops in different methods and materials, including clay-based plasters, cob, rammed earth and adobe, straw bale and hempcrete. House tours will feature different building techniques, including straw bale and rammed earth, adobe, natural plasters and more.

description:
Destination Earth, Expect your senses to be stirred in a new art installation. Destination Earth aims to inspire climate action through art. It incorporates satellite data, real-time generative music, and responds to audience movement in real-time. Using video and immersive sound, audiences will be challenged to reconsider the rhythm of living as humans. 
You are invited to dive into the flow of the Southern Ocean and explore the pulse of the Antarctic circumpolar current. Participate by adjusting your walking patterns and breathing to ‘regenerate’ the world around you. Motion sensors will pick up your activity and adjust the environment to suit. At a sensorial level the effects of climate change will come to life. 

Destination Earth is a collaboration between Cellule Studio (UK) and Victoria University of Wellington. The work, by artist Salome Bazin, mixes art, science, and technology. It emphasises the urgent need to slow down human activity.  

A bi-cultural perspective is also central to the experience. Māori symbolic views of the ocean are included, offering a richer narrative of the global climate.
 
Image credit: Cellule Studio, directed by Salomé Bazin.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Electrify the Hutt Expo 2025, The Electrify the Hutt Expo is charging into Lower Hutt with a mission to spark inspiration and supercharge your lifestyle with the power of clean electricity. As energy bills climb and climate concerns grow, this high-energy event will show you how to take control—cut costs, slash emissions, and embrace a smarter, more sustainable way of living.
Discover the incredible potential of generating your own local power through solar panels, micro wind turbines, and more. With dynamic demos, interactive exhibits, and expert talks, you'll learn how easy and empowering it is to electrify your home, reduce your reliance on fossil fuels, and enjoy the long-term benefits of clean energy.
But that’s just the beginning. The expo goes beyond saving money and helping the planet—it’s about building stronger, more resilient communities. By embracing local energy generation, we can protect ourselves from rising energy costs, power outages, and climate extremes. It’s about creating homes and neighbourhoods that are not just efficient, but future-proof.
So whether you're a curious homeowner, a savvy business owner, or just someone who wants to be part of something positive, Electrify the Hutt is your place to plug in. Come connect with experts, explore cutting-edge tech, and join a growing movement to electrify our lives and build a cleaner, brighter Hutt Valley for everyone.
Add the date to your calendar now!

description:
Absolute Beginners Social Dancing Introductory Class, Ever wanted to be one of people who get up on the dancefloor and look like they know what they're doing? Have you secretly had aspirations of dancing like Ginger Rogers and Fred Astaire? Have you thought that learning social dancing might be fun but not wanted to commit to a whole term of classes? Well here is a one-hour class to give it all a try and totally FREE!
The class will cover two simple building blocks, which form the basis of five dances: Waltz, Foxtrot, Rumba, Cha Cha, and East Coast Swing.
Partners always welcome but not a requirement to enrol.
DATE: Wednesday, 3 September 2025
TIME: 6-7pm
PLACE: Level 2, 110 Hutt Rd, Kaiwharawhara, Wellington
COST: FREE!
This Introductory Class will be followed by a seven-week course to develop these building blocks and practice the five named dances. While we hope you will sign up to the course there is no obligation, whatsoever.
Come and experience the relaxed and fun atmosphere of social dancing, enjoying the music and company, and learn a new skill that will have all the people watching wishing they could dance like you!
Come give it a try!

description:
GDNZ 2025 Shelly Bay Cleanup, Join Ghost Diving New Zealand for a community cleanup!

This will be an ocean and shore based clean up targeting rubbish in and around the Wellington foreshore.

Scuba divers, free divers and shore crew all needed! Be prepared to get wet and dirty!

DATE: Saturday October 11th 2025

TIMES:
9.00am - Registrations open
9:45am - Briefing
10.00am - Divers in the water
2.00pm Clean-up and pack down

LOCATION: Shelly Bay - look for the GDNZ signs.

Scuba Divers who wish to participate must have a minimum of 30 logged dives and be comfortable working in low / zero visibility.
Scuba and Free Divers must provide their own gear and tanks. If you also have your own catch bag(s) or float boat for collecting rubbish, please bring this along and ensure they are named.
If you would like to join in the fun and participate as part of the shore crew, you will need to make sure you are wearing fully covered shoes and bring a pair of gardening gloves... also be prepared to get dirty!

ALL PARTICIPANTS, SHORE CREW AND DIVERS MUST REGISTER ON ARRIVAL.

PLEASE NOTE:
• This is a free, family friendly event, but children must be supervised at all times by an adult.
• Closed toe footwear must be worn for safety.
• Please bring your own hand protection (gardening gloves or similar).
• Don’t forget your own water bottle and bring sunscreen if it’s a warm day.
• Dress for the weather (warm clothes and jackets)
• There will also be plenty of work for non-divers to get involved.
Should the event be cancelled due to circumstances out of our control, notification will be given on the Facebook page the night before. Please remember to check prior to the event.
We look forward to seeing you there!

Hātaitai Spring Seed Swap, Keen to get your garden going?
Come along Sat 6 Sept to swap any seeds you don’t need and get a start on the spring planting season.
Don’t know when or how best to sow your seeds? We can show you and get you going!
As always there will be some free tea and coffee (sponsored by Peoples Coffee), maybe even some home baking too!

Spare seeds
Seedlings (aren’t you keen!)
Spare potting mix
Spare seedling trays
Based on a Crop Swap these events aim to connect the community and reduce food & produce waste, and encourage sustainable practices.
WHAT IS CROP SWAP?
It is a wonderful welcoming monthly community gathering to share the abundance from our kitchens and gardens!
Been madly making chutney? Silver beet going crazy? Been collecting flower seeds? Got some foraged berries or a delicious cake to share?
Come along for a kōrero with our friendly community and enjoy free coffee, usually with a scone or muffin that someone has brought along. Everyone is welcome - with or without something to share.
You can find us upstairs at the Hataitai Bowling Club, 157 Hataitai Rd. We gather from 12pm with the event / swap part kicking off at 12:30pm SEE YOU THERE!
(Thanks @CropSwapTeWhanganuiaTara for support and ideas!)

description:
Launching in-store: Capital Trees by Susette Goldsmith, Join us in celebrating the recent launch of Capital Trees: The Arboreal Legacy of Te Upoko-O-te-Ika the Wellington Region by Susette Goldsmith, author/editor of Tree Sense: Ways of Thinking About Trees.
"The significance and meaning of trees engagingly explored through the way they have shaped our capital.
From the fossil forest of Tītahi Bay and the ageing oak on Plimmer Steps, to the karaka grove on Wellington’s waterfront and a threatened stand of lowland beech in the Hutt Valley, Capital Trees journeys across the region to trace the living legacies of the city’s rich tree heritage and the many people who have shaped, protected and challenged it.
These legacies include arguments around heritage tree listing, the native versus exotics debate, biodiversity, attitudes towards heritage authenticity, trees as monuments and more, explored through facts, anecdotes and field notes.
Illustrated with contemporary photography and specimen illustrations of the species and individual trees covered, this book is a must for all who live in the Wellington region."
All welcome! See you at the signing table.
label: Conservation & Environment

This will be followed by an action-focused discussion led by chef and grower Mara Masarotti on how to connect urban growers with spaces to grow kai at scale.

description:
Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) Conference 2026, Kia ora!
Electricity and electrification are seen as the significant enablers for decarbonisation of our nation. The Future Architecture of the Network (FAN) | Te Whatunga Hiko programme aspires to meet the challenges the electrical power system will face as we journey towards sustainable decarbonisation.
Our vision is to provide an infrastructure paradigm through a hybrid AC/DC transmission and distribution system that meets the needs of tomorrow’s efficient, low-carbon, reliable and resilient electrical power system.
Funded as part of the New Zealand Government’s Strategic Science Investment Fund (SSIF) on Advanced Energy Technology Platform (AETP), the research team is investigating what the future electrical power system might look like.
Hear about the team’s latest achievements as we approach the final phase of the programme.
Attendance is in person at Victoria University Wellington.
Ngā mihi nui,
Prof. Neville Watson,
Science Leader
The detailed programme will be circulated closer to the event.
 More information on the research can be found at https://www.fan.ac.nz/
If you have any questions, please contact futurearchitecturenetwork@canterbury.ac.nz

description:
Manawa Karioi Working Bees, Our track maintenance and planting working bees are focussing on plant species diversity rather than large planting quantities. We have ordered 500 special trees from the Berhampore Nursery. We are in this for the long haul and a forest that contains a wide range of plant species will, in turn, attract a wider range of birds, lizards, and invertebrates. A wider range of plant species also allows for the forest to naturally regenerate and helps prevent weed species from establishing.
Tools are provided, bring sturdy shoes and a water bottle, Working bees are held every Sunday in June (except June 1st - Kings Birthday Weekend) and August 2025.
Meeting at the Information Shelter in the Tapu te Ranga Marae car park at the end of Danube Street in Island Bay. Children are welcome with parents or guardians.

description:
Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate, Levin | "Waste-Ed" with Kate
Landfills are designed to last 1,000 years! In this chaotic time of consumerism and climate change, we are facing some big challenges that we need to start facing head on! You can do nothing, and nothing will change, or you can be an imperative cog in the machine that works towards a healthier planet. If you want a place to start your waste minimisation journey or even want to reinforce what you already know, then this 2-hour seminar is for you!

Why join us? You will:

LEARN about what happens to our waste once it leaves the curbside.
ACQUIRE tips/tricks and life hacks that will help you deal with/manage your waste better.
BE CHALLENGED to reduce your waste.

Don't miss out on this opportunity full of witty humor, reality checks, and encouragement that may also challenge your thinking around trash! Secure your spot in this 2-hour seminar today by buying a ticket.
label: Conservation & Environment

description:
Manu Park Site Viewing, Manu Park Site Viewing
Meet us and find out how you can build your dream home in a new subdivision that combines outstanding natural beauty and a real sense of community.
The agent is on-site at the end of Karuhiruhi Street every Sunday between 10.00am - 11.00am.
Since its establishment in 2018, Manu Park has become a highly sought-after community, with Stages One and Two fully sold out. Don’t miss your chance to secure a piece of this paradise in Stage 3, where only 8 sections remain.
Manu Park isn’t just a place to live—it’s a place to belong. Designed with families in mind, it offers a safe and welcoming environment where kids can ride their bikes down quiet streets, explore nature on their doorstep, and grow up knowing their neighbours. Centrally located near Waikanae township it offers expansive open spaces and a strong sense of community; Manu Park is a neighbourhood where friendships flourish and families thrive.
Nestled within protected native bush, Manu Park offers breathtaking surroundings, generously sized sections, and the opportunity to build a home tailored to your vision and lifestyle. Named after the Māori word for bird, it sits beside the renowned Nga Manu Nature Reserve, close to Waikanae’s excellent schools and amenities, just minutes from the beach, and under an hour from Wellington city.
Teaming up with local building companies, Manu Park offers House and Land packages for a seamless home-building experience. Visit Manu Park to explore Design and Build opportunities to create a home that perfectly fits your lifestyle.
Don’t miss this rare opportunity to be part of a vibrant community where nature and modern living come together. Visit manupark.nz to learn more and secure your section today

Meet at Pukehuia Park at 10.30am to collect protective gear and rubbish bags, and then head out around our neighbourhood to collect what you can. You might like to head to somewhere you know is particularly rubbish-y around our suburb.

Bring your friends and neighbours and join the fun and satisfaction of making our home a nicer place.

description:
Lunch & Learn with David Trubridge, Join us for a very special Teulo Lunch & Learn, where design, sustainability, and community regeneration come together.
Hosted by Häfele and Teulo, this intimate event features internationally renowned designer David Trubridge and the global launch of his newest portable light: Dusk.
Enjoy lunch and conversation with peers from across the design and construction industry, with MC DK guiding the session.
What to Expect
Keynote: Think Like a Tree
In his 20-minute talk on biophilic design, David Trubridge shares how we can learn from trees and forests to design healthier, more sustainable spaces.
Film Screening: Think Like a Forest
This short film from Pure Advantage highlights the Recloaking Papatūānuku movement, an ambitious initiative to restore more than 2 million hectares of native forest and wetland in Aotearoa. Featuring Sam the Trap Man and local kaitiaki, it’s both an inspiration and a call to action.
Global Launch: The Dusk Lamp
Be among the first to experience Dusk, David’s most portable light yet, inspired by his collaboration with Pure Salt’s Tamatea Art Project in Fiordland. A new short documentary will showcase the story behind the design and the environmental partnership that shaped it. A portion of all sales will support Pure Salt’s conservation efforts in Dusky Sound.
Local Conservation Panel
Hear from organisations leading vital regeneration work, including the Maraetōtara Tree Trust, Esk River planting projects, and Te Mata Peak Park restoration, and learn how you can get involved.
Why Attend?
This Lunch & Learn is more than a product launch or film screening — it’s a chance to connect with the design community, hear from one of New Zealand’s most iconic designers, and explore practical steps toward a regenerative future.

description:
Resilience and Emissions Reduction Workshop for Not-For-Profits | Blenheim, Ready your not-for-profit for the future
Do you know you need to take action to address climate change but don’t know where to start?
Do you want to strengthen your organisations’ planning and readiness for change?
Do you want practical tools and support to measure, assess, and report on your organisations’ impact?

In partnership with Rātā Foundation, our Earth+ Resilience and Emissions Reduction programme has been designed to flip the script on climate change, centering your organisation as agents of change and kitting you with the tools, support and community to make a difference; and it’s free of charge!
About the programme
With the support of the Terra Nova team and other programme participants, you will be guided to identify how your organisation is uniquely placed to contribute to the resilience and wellbeing of people and planet, and the opportunities and obstacles to creating positive change.
The programme is accessible and suitable for everyone, from those just starting on the journey, to those who have steps in place but are looking to gain access to further resources. This programme is not intended to add extra workload or deliverables for your organisation, it is an offer of support to integrate an Earth+ approach into your BAU; an answer to the question “what can we do about climate change?”
We know that every organisation’s capacity is different, so our support is available for you to utilise it when you need it until the end of 2025. This includes:
Access to a dedicated online community where you can connect with the Terra Nova team, other Rātā grantees and specialised partners. Ask questions, find resources and share your journey.
A toolkit of resources and impact sessions to develop your knowledge and connect you with the expertise and support to build resilience and tackle change in a range of impact areas.
Complementary access to the Cogo carbon emissions measurement tool, providing you the ability to quantify and report on your emissions impact and providing recommended actions for emissions reduction and cost savings, in an easy-to-use format.
It begins with a 1-day interactive workshop to kick things off. By the end of the workshop, you will walk away:
Feeling more empowered about the future, with a deeper understanding of resilience and climate change as it relates to your organisation’s context.
Having explored how you can make change positive and achievable, centered on the needs of your community and team. 
With free access to Cogo carbon manager, an emissions profile, report of your carbon footprint and practical action you can take to reduce your emissions.
Having built a network of support and gained free-to-use practical tools and templates.
Note: we will be running multiple workshops throughout the year; you only need to attend one workshop to join the programme. If you prefer an alternate date, please head to our Humanitix profile to find the corresponding event. 
The programme is fully funded for not-for-profit organisations and registrations are now open for 2025! Register for the programme and secure your spot in a workshop through this Humanatix event, and a member of the Terra Nova team will be in touch to confirm your enrollment. For more information about the programme and workshop, visit the Terra Nova website.
We look forward to welcoming you into our community of changemakers!

Meet at the Duck Pond in the Main Garden
Cost: $5 (cash only, please). or free for Friends.

This is part of the regular walks run by the Friends of the Wellington Botanic Garden, they run twice monthly throughout the year with a different topic every time.
